data.title: The Best Samsung Phones of 2025, Tested and Reviewed | WIRED
data.content: The Best Samsung Phones of 2025, Tested and Reviewed | WIRED Skip to main content Open Navigation Menu Menu Search Search Security Politics The Big Story Business Science Culture Reviews Newsletters Podcasts Video The Big Interview Magazine Merch Travel Steven Levy's Plaintext Column Events WIRED Insider WIRED Consulting Coupons Open Earbuds Best Motorola Phones Smart Glasses Which Mattress? Buy It for Life The WIRED 101 Deals Delivered Julian Chokkattu Gear Jun 7, 2025 8:38 AM The Best Samsung Phones From flagship and budget to flipping and folding, Samsung’s Galaxy range spans the breadth of the smartphone cosmos. WIRED’s here to help you make your choice. Save this story Save Save this story Save All products featured on WIRED are independently selected by our editors. However, we may receive compensation from retailers and/or from purchases of products through these links. Featured in this article The Best Samsung Phone(s) Samsung Galaxy S25 and S25+ Read more $800 $719 Amazon Best Upgrade Samsung Galaxy S25 Ultra Read more $1,299 Amazon A Respectable Midrange Phone Samsung Galaxy S24 FE Read more $650 $525 Amazon Best Budget Samsung Phone Samsung Galaxy A26 Read more $300 Samsung Show more 4 / 8 There's the iPhone, and then there are Galaxy phones. Whereas Apple is the sole company behind the iOS mobile operating system, even the best Samsung phones face stiff competition in the Android world. (And yes, Galaxy phones are Android phones , though Samsung calls its layer over Android “One UI.”) Google's Pixel phones are my favorite Android phones , but Samsung devices are just as great and often have better hardware. Alongside Google, it has the longest software support for its cheap and high-end devices. That means you don't have to upgrade your phone as often, as it will stay up-to-date, secure, and free of bugs for longer. But the Korean giant has many, many models at varying prices. What's the best Samsung phone? I sort it out here, starting with the Galaxy S25 . I also have tips and tricks to get the most out of your shiny new hardware. Check out our mobile guides, including the Best Samsung Galaxy S25 Cases , Best Galaxy S24 Cases , Best Android Phones , Best Cheap Phones , Best Pixel Phones , and Best Folding Phones . Updated June 2025: We've added the Galaxy S25 Edge, Galaxy A16, Galaxy A26, and Galaxy A36. We've also added details about the upcoming Galaxy Z Fold7 and Flip7. Why Buy Samsung? AccordionItemContainerButton LargeChevron The best part of being in the world of Android is choice of hardware. Want a phone with a headphone jack? Sure ! Want a gaming phone with two USB-C ports? Why not . Want a phone that fast-charges in around 30 minutes? It exists . So why stick with the stalwart Samsung? In my experience and research, Samsung's smartphones have a track record of reliability, and because it's a major player, it has a wider network of authorized repair centers than competing Android manufacturers. Yes, I remember the Galaxy Note 7 fiasco and even the issues with the first-gen Galaxy Fold , but Samsung now has a customer satisfaction score equal to Apple, according to the American Customer Satisfaction Index . That said, I haven't read great things about the company's US customer support team. With its flagship phones, you're getting top-of-the-line specs and exceptional build quality with long software support. I primarily pick Pixel phones over Samsung because I prefer Google's software experience, but there are plenty of people who like Samsung's take on Android. As always, keep an open mind and consider all the other options available to you. Is Now the Best Time to Buy? AccordionItemContainerButton LargeChevron Samsung's Galaxy S25 series arrived early in the year, meaning if you want a new flagship, it's a great time to buy. It also has debuted most of its budget phones for 2025, so if money's tight, you have a new options to consider. However, it's worth keeping the company's launch time frames in mind if you only want the latest and greatest. The flagship Galaxy S series launches at the start of the year during Samsung's Galaxy Unpacked event. The Galaxy S25 series, for example, was announced on January 22 and launched on February 7. The budget Galaxy A series typically arrives in the spring (April or May). There are several A series phones so they usually dribble out during the first few months of the year. This year, there's the Galaxy A16, A26, A36, and A56. The A56 has not launched yet in the US. The folding Galaxy Z series have always launched in the summer, and this year's event is coming up this July during Samsung's second and last Galaxy Unpacked of the year. I would hold off on buying a folding Samsung phone until then. The midrange Galaxy FE series is the “Fan Edition,” but this is more or less a slightly cheaper variant of the Galaxy S series. It typically launches in the fall, around late September or October. Consider these dates as you shop, because you may want to h...

These are the best Samsung phones.","mainEntityOfPage":{"@type":"WebPage","@id":"https://www.wired.com/gallery/best-samsung-phones/"},"publisher":{"@context":"https://schema.org","@type":"Organization","name":"WIRED","logo":{"@type":"ImageObject","url":"https://www.wired.com/verso/static/wired-us/assets/newsletter-signup-hub.jpg","width":"500px","height":"100px"},"url":"https://www.wired.com"}}</script><script type="application/ld+json">{"@context":"https://schema.org/","@type":"BreadcrumbList","itemListElement":[{"@type":"ListItem","position":1,"name":"Gear","item":"https://www.wired.com/gear/"},{"@type":"ListItem","position":2,"name":"Shopping","item":"https://www.wired.com/tag/shopping/"},{"@type":"ListItem","position":3,"name":"The Best Samsung Phones"}]}</script><script type="application/ld+json">{"@context":"https://schema.org","@type":"ItemList","url":"https://www.wired.com/gallery/best-samsung-phones/","numberOfItems":8,"itemListElement":[{"@context":"https://schema.org","@type":"ListItem","position":1,"item":{"@type":"Product","name":"Galaxy S25 and S25+","brand":{"@type":"Brand","name":"Samsung"},"url":"https://www.wired.com/gallery/best-samsung-phones/#67a4570388c8f13c80c0c157","image":["https://media.wired.com/photos/67a62a9df249072ca3e37dc4/4:3/w_960,c_limit/Samsung-Galaxy-S25-and-S25+-Reviewer-Photo-SOURCE-Julian-Chokkattu.jpg"],"description":"The first place to start when considering a Samsung phone is the Galaxy S25 series (7/10, WIRED Recommends), the company's current flagship lineup. Not much has changed from its predecessors (seriously, many of the specs are identical), but that doesn't stop them from being excellent and reliable smartphones. The Galaxy S25 is the smallest of the lot with a 6.2-inch screen, and then there's the Galaxy S25+ at 6.7 inches—choosing between them largely depends on whether you want a small, pocketable phone or a big display. There are minuscule differences in some specs, such as how the S25+ comes with 256 GB of storage, and the bigger size means a beefier battery, but they're more alike than ever before.\nYou get every high-end feature you can think of, from UFS 4.0 storage speeds to brilliantly bright AMOLED displays with high 120-Hz refresh rates that ratchet down to 1 Hz to be more energy efficient. The batteries typically last a full day of average use with around 30 to 40 percent left, and there's an excellent triple-camera system with 3x optical zoom, an ultrawide in addition to the main camera, and a strong selfie shooter. These phones also put out some of the best video footage out of the box, so they're great for budding TikTokkers. Arguably, the most notable improvement over prior models is performance—the efficient Snapdragon 8 Elite chipset paired with Samsung's improved cooling technology means it can handle demanding games like Genshin Impact with fewer stutters and without getting warm too quickly. I'm not fond of the design—they're a bit bland—but at least you can snag them in some unique colors exclusive to Samsung.com.\nSamsung focused on several Galaxy AI features in this release, like making Google's Gemini the default voice assistant when you press and hold the power button. Gemini can now integrate with multiple apps—native Samsung and Google apps—so you can ask it to find the games for your favorite basketball team and add them to your calendar. Some of these AI features, outlined here, are helpful, while others, like Now Brief, are not.\n\n\n\nSpecs: Galaxy S25\nGalaxy S25+\n\n\n\n\nDisplay: 6.2 inches, 120-Hz LTPO, AMOLED\n6.7 inches, 120-Hz LTPO, AMOLED\n\n\nProcessor and RAM: Qualcomm Snapdragon 8 Elite with 12 GB of RAM\nQualcomm Snapdragon 8 Elite with 12 GB of RAM\n\n\nStorage: 128, 256, and 512 GB\n256 and 512 GB\n\n\nBattery: 4,000 mAh\n4,900 mAh\n\n\nCameras: 50-MP main camera, 12-MP ultrawide, 10-MP telephoto (3x), and 12-MP selfie camera\n50-MP main camera, 12-MP ultrawide, 10-MP telephoto (3x), and 12-MP selfie camera\n\n\nUpdates (from date of manufacture): 7 years\n7 years\n\n\nExtras: Non-magnetic Qi 2.1 wireless charging (Qi2 Ready with case). That'd be the Galaxy S25 Ultra (7/10, WIRED Recommends), though it doesn't feel as “ultra” as its predecessors. This phone shares many specs and features with the standard Galaxy S25 series—even the design is unified—but it has more durable front glass for better drop protection and scratch resistance, as well as a titanium frame. However, this doesn't mean it's less prone to breakage (use a case!). It's the biggest phone of the trio, meaning it has the largest battery, which can extend into the morning of a second day. Notably, the S25 Ultra has a built-in stylus—you pull it out from the bottom and start writing on the screen to jot down notes or doodle when bored on a Zoom call. Unfortunately, Samsung removed the ability to use it as a Bluetooth remote for the camera.\nSpeaking of, the cameras are where it goes the extra mile—not only is the main camera a 200-megapixel shooter that can preserve more details, but there are also two telephoto cameras in addition to the new and improved 50-megapixel ultrawide. At 3x and 5x, you have better zoom options with great quality, though this starts to diminish in low light. (I do miss the 10x optical zoom from the Galaxy S23.) The ultrawide also performs well in low light and has delivered sharper results than the Google Pixel 9 Pro and iPhone 16 Pro Max.\nBut just because this is Samsung's top-of-the-line phone, it doesn't mean this is the right phone for you. If you don't care about a stylus and don't use the zoom functions on a smartphone camera much, there are few reasons to spend so much on the S25 Ultra.\n\n\n\nSpecs\n\n\n\n\nDisplay: 6.9 inches, 120-Hz LTPO, AMOLED\n\n\nProcessor and RAM: Snapdragon 8 Elite with 12 GB RAM\n\n\nStorage: 256-GB, 512-GB, and 1-TB options\n\n\nBattery: 5,000 mAh\n\n\nCameras: 200-MP main, 50-MP ultrawide, 10-MP telephoto (3X), 50-MP telephoto (5X), and 12-MP selfie camera\n\n\nUpdates (from date of manufacture): 7 years\n\n\nExtras: Non-magnetic Qi 2.1 wireless charging (Qi2 Ready with case). IP68. In any case, the S24 FE is only worth buying if you can catch it on sale for around $500 or below—anything more, and you may as well buy a Galaxy S24 (used or new), or wait for the Galaxy S25 to dip on sale.\nI used the S24 FE for close to a month and had a perfectly fine time with it. It uses Samsung's Exynos processor, and I haven't had any performance issues whatsoever; my benchmark scores put it a smidge below the Galaxy S24 and its Snapdragon chipset. You still get access to all the original Galaxy AI features, nearly the same triple-camera experience, the 7-year software update policy, and perks like IP68 water resistance and wireless charging. What you miss out on are a higher resolution display, extra RAM, and more storage options. The bezels are a smidge thicker around the screen, which doesn't support LTPO (the tech that allows the display to move from 1 Hz to 120 Hz to conserve battery life). The fingerprint scanner is also optical and not ultrasonic, and while it's been quite responsive for me, ultrasonic scanners are often more reliable. Battery life has been solid; after several weeks of use, I average 30 percent left in the tank by midnight, and that's with a few hours of GPS navigation and music streaming thrown in, not to mention too many hours of riffling through Instagram Reels.\n\n\n\nSpecs\n\n\n\n\nDisplay: 6.7 inch, 120 Hz, AMOLED\n\n\nProcessor and RAM: Samsung Exynos 2400e with 8 GB of RAM\n\n\nStorage: 128 GB\n\n\nBattery: 4,700 mAh\n\n\nCameras: 50-MP main camera, 12-MP ultrawide, 8-MP telephoto (3x), and 10-MP selfie camera\n\n\nUpdates (from date of manufacture): 7 years\n\n\nExtras: Wireless charging, IP68, fingerprint unlock, NFC\n\n\nCarrier compatibility: Works on all three major US networks","offers":[{"@type":"Offer","name":"Galaxy S24 FE","price":"525","priceCurrency":"USD","url":"https://www.amazon.com/dp/B0DCLD9PLY","offeredBy":{"@type":"Organization","name":"Amazon"}},{"@type":"Offer","name":"Galaxy S24 FE","price":"525","priceCurrency":"USD","url":"https://www.samsung.com/us/smartphones/galaxy-s24-fe/buy/galaxy-s24-fe-128gb-unlocked-sm-s721uzkaxaa/","offeredBy":{"@type":"Organization","name":"Samsung"}},{"@type":"Offer","name":"Galaxy S24 FE","price":"525","priceCurrency":"USD","url":"https://www.bestbuy.com/site/samsung-galaxy-s24-fe-128gb-unlocked-graphite/6599405.p?skuId=6599405","offeredBy":{"@type":"Organization","name":"Best Buy"}}]}},{"@context":"https://schema.org","@type":"ListItem","position":4,"item":{"@type":"Product","name":"Galaxy A26","brand":{"@type":"Brand","name":"Samsung"},"url":"https://www.wired.com/gallery/best-samsung-phones/#684312e330923e2a12cd9216","image":["https://media.wired.com/photos/684367923c448a9bc4a5dc8e/4:3/w_960,c_limit/Galaxy%20A26%20SOURCE%20Julian%20Chokkattu.png"],"description":"Samsung makes solid budget phones, but not the best. I highly recommend glossing through my Best Cheap Phones guide because you might be better served with a Pixel 9a, Nothing Phone (3a), or Moto G Power. But if you want to stick with Samsung, the Galaxy A26 is the best at the moment (6/10, WIRED Review). It's not flashy—the glossy black design is dull and attracts a ton of smudges and dust—but it has many of the features you want for not much money.\nPerformance is standout here. The Exynos 1380 delivers a mostly smooth experience, with few stutters, and the 120-Hz 6.7-inch screen helps things feel fluid. The screen is bright enough to read on sunny days, though the colors get washed out at the max brightness. This is one of the last few Samsung phones with a microSD card slot, if that matters to you, so you can expand storage on top of the base 128 GB. The battery easily lasts a full day with average use, and the best part is Samsung will deliver 6 years of updates—OS and security patches—which is unparalleled at this price.\n\n\n\nSpecs\n\n\n\n\nDisplay: 6.7-inch 120 Hz, AMOLED\n\n\nProcessor and RAM: Samsung Exynos 1380 with 6 GB of RAM\n\n\nStorage: 128 GB with microSD slot\n\n\nBattery: 5,000 mAh\n\n\nCameras: 50-MP main camera, 8-MP ultrawide, 2-MP macro, and 13-MP selfie camera\n\n\nUpdates (from date of manufacture): 6 years\n\n\nExtras: IP67, eSIM, NFC, fingerprint unlock\n\n\nCarrier compatibility: Works on all three major US networks","offers":[{"@type":"Offer","name":"Galaxy A26","price":"300","priceCurrency":"USD","url":"https://www.samsung.com/us/smartphones/galaxy-a26/buy/galaxy-a26-5g-128gb-unlocked-sm-a266uzkaxaa/","offeredBy":{"@type":"Organization","name":"Samsung"}}]}},{"@context":"https://schema.org","@type":"ListItem","position":5,"item":{"@type":"Product","name":"Galaxy S25 Edge","brand":{"@type":"Brand","name":"Samsung"},"url":"https://www.wired.com/gallery/best-samsung-phones/#6830b23d9ff9f250ab203aa2","image":["https://media.wired.com/photos/6831137f6efa792c1c1cc0f9/4:3/w_960,c_limit/Samsung%20Galaxy%20S25%20Edge_%20Photograph%20Julian%20Chokkattu.png"],"description":"Have you ever wanted a really thin and lightweight phone? No? Well, Samsung has an option for you anyway. The late-entry Galaxy S25 Edge sits in the middle of Samsung's flagship lineup and matches several features of the Galaxy S25 Ultra, like a titanium frame, stronger front glass, and 4K 120 fps video recording. All the cameras even have autofocus. But it made several sacrifices to achieve its amazingly slim 5.8-mm frame (for context, the S25 Ultra is 8.2 mm thick). There's no stylus, no telephoto camera, and worst of all, the battery capacity has been slashed.\nWe've seen this before—thin phones have always compromised on battery life, and that's no different here. I constantly had to baby this phone's 3,900-mAh battery with average to heavy usage, and that's just not acceptable for a $1,100 smartphone today. If you find yourself constantly near a power source and you think you'll enjoy the slim and light design, then go for it. It's still an excellent flagship in many other ways. But battery life is routinely a top concern for most people, and it'll disappoint here.\n\n\n\nSpecs\nSamsung Galaxy S25 Edge\n\n\n\n\nDisplay:\n6.7 inch, 120 Hz, AMOLED\n\n\nProcessor and RAM:\nQualcomm Snapdragon 8 Elite with 12 GB RAM\n\n\nStorage:\n256- and 512-GB options\n\n\nBattery:\n3,900 mAh\n\n\nCameras:\n200-MP main, 12-MP ultrawide, 12-MP selfie camera\n\n\nUpdates:\n7 years\n\n\nExtras:\nQi2 Ready 15-watt wireless charging, 25-watt fast charging, IP68, titanium frame, NFC, fingerprint unlock\n\n\nCarrier compatibility:\nWorks on all three major US networks","offers":[{"@type":"Offer","name":"Galaxy S25 Edge","price":"1100","priceCurrency":"USD","url":"https://www.amazon.com/Smartphone-Unlocked-Processor-Manufacturer-Warranty/dp/B0DYVL6DB5","offeredBy":{"@type":"Organization","name":"Amazon"}},{"@type":"Offer","name":"Galaxy S25 Edge","price":"1100","priceCurrency":"USD","url":"https://www.samsung.com/us/smartphones/galaxy-s25-edge/buy/galaxy-s25-edge-512gb-unlocked-sku-sm-s937uzsexaa/","offeredBy":{"@type":"Organization","name":"Samsung"}},{"@type":"Offer","name":"Galaxy S25 Edge","price":"1100","priceCurrency":"USD","url":"https://www.bestbuy.com/site/samsung-galaxy-s25-edge-512gb-unlocked-titanium-silver/6624975.p?skuId=6624975","offeredBy":{"@type":"Organization","name":"Best Buy"}}]}},{"@context":"https://schema.org","@type":"ListItem","position":6,"item":{"@type":"Product","name":"Galaxy Z Flip6","brand":{"@type":"Brand","name":"Samsung"},"url":"https://www.wired.com/gallery/best-samsung-phones/#67173d1b4579622521b74822","image":["https://media.wired.com/photos/67edf7522bbb28d0f4739de9/4:3/w_960,c_limit/Samsung-Galaxy-Z-Flip6,-a-foldable-phone-showing-the-exterior-screen-and-cameras-(no-border).jpg"],"description":"Note: Samsung is expected to unveil the Galaxy Z Flip7 in July at its next Galaxy Unpacked event. I recommend holding off on the Z Flip6.\nWant something with a little more personality? Samsung has been making folding smartphones longer than any other company, and the Galaxy Z Flip6 is the most refined version to date (7/10, WIRED Review). It's not my favorite flip-style folding phone—that'd be the Motorola Razr Ultra and its larger external screen—but the Flip6 is a close second, and it one-ups Motorola's device on a few fronts. The hinge design is more responsive and feels more durable, plus there's longer software support and better cameras.\nThe main reason to buy a flippy folding phone? You get a normal-sized smartphone with the ability to fold it in half, perfect for smaller pockets, and it's just easier to carry. The main drawback? Battery life isn't great. Even with average use, there's a good chance you may need a top-up before the day's end. Make sure to bring a battery pack! Also, while Samsung added a vapor chamber system for better cooling in this model, my unit still gave me a notification that the device needed to cool down after using GPS navigation on a hot day in Paris.\nBut a folding phone's best trick is with its cameras: You can take selfies with the Flip6's superior rear cameras by folding the device into a 90-degree angle and using the external display as a camera viewfinder to ensure you're in the shot. Read my Best Folding Phones guide for more flipping fun.\n\n\n\nSpecs\n\n\n\n\nExternal display: 3.4 inches, 60 Hz, AMOLED\n\n\nInternal display: 6.7-inch, 120-Hz LTPO, AMOLED\n\n\nProcessor and RAM: Snapdragon 8 Gen 3 with 12 GB RAM\n\n\nStorage: 256- or 512-GB options\n\n\nBattery: 4,000 mAh\n\n\nCameras: 50-MP main camera, 12-MP ultrawide, 10-MP selfie camera\n\n\nUpdates (from date of manufacture): 7 years\n\n\nExtras: IPX8, fingerprint sensor, NFC, wireless charging\n\n\nCarrier compatibility: Works on all three major US networks","offers":[{"@type":"Offer","name":"Galaxy Z Flip6","price":"900","priceCurrency":"USD","url":"https://www.amazon.com/SAMSUNG-Smartphone-Camcorder-Interpreter-Manufacturer/dp/B0D192WWZ9","offeredBy":{"@type":"Organization","name":"Amazon"}},{"@type":"Offer","name":"Galaxy Z Flip6","price":"1100","priceCurrency":"USD","url":"https://www.samsung.com/us/smartphones/galaxy-z-flip6/buy/galaxy-z-flip6-256gb-unlocked-sm-f741ulbaxaa/","offeredBy":{"@type":"Organization","name":"Samsung"}},{"@type":"Offer","name":"Galaxy Z Flip6","price":"950","priceCurrency":"USD","url":"https://www.bestbuy.com/site/samsung-galaxy-z-flip6-256gb-unlocked-silver-shadow/6586735.p?skuId=6586735","offeredBy":{"@type":"Organization","name":"Best Buy"}}]}},{"@context":"https://schema.org","@type":"ListItem","position":7,"item":{"@type":"Product","name":"Galaxy Z Fold6","brand":{"@type":"Brand","name":"Samsung"},"url":"https://www.wired.com/gallery/best-samsung-phones/#67173d1d67f4b662eedb19bd","image":["https://media.wired.com/photos/668da4a9ec66f49a22616809/4:3/w_960,c_limit/Galaxy%20Z%20Fold6.jpg"],"description":"Note: Samsung is expected to unveil the Galaxy Z Fold7 in July at its Galaxy Unpacked event. I recommend holding off on the Z Fold7.\nIf money is no object and you love two screens on your desktop, you'll probably like the Galaxy Z Fold6 (7/10, WIRED Review). This iteration has a close to “normal” smartphone experience on the exterior 6.3-inch screen. It's still a bit narrow, but it's more usable than its predecessors. Open the phone up and there's a vast 7.6-inch AMOLED screen staring at your face, turning this folding phone into a tiny tablet. You can use your apps in this full-sized view (it's especially great when these apps are tablet-optimized), or you can use split-screen and get two normal-looking app windows next to each other. A persistent taskbar follows you throughout the interface like the dock on MacOS or Windows, letting you hop into another app at a moment's notice. It's great for getting stuff done.\nUnfortunately, the 2024 model got a price bump despite minor changes, and the competition also feels like it has blown past what Samsung has been doing for years—the Pixel 9 Pro Fold has an even more normal exterior screen, and the OnePlus Open has richer multitasking capabilities. Honor's folding phone is also the world's thinnest. Rumors suggest the Galaxy Z Fold7 will be a bigger upgrade with new features and capabilities, so you should wait to see what's new. On the other hand, Samsung is set up to have the best repair network if something goes wrong, and the build quality of the Fold6 is excellent.\n\n\n\nSpecs\n\n\n\n\nExternal display: 6.3-inch, 120-Hz LTPO, AMOLED\n\n\nInternal display: 7.6-inch, 120-Hz LTPO, AMOLED\n\n\nProcessor and RAM: Snapdragon 8 Gen 3 with 12 GB RAM\n\n\nStorage: 256, 512 GB, or 1 TB options\n\n\nBattery: 4,400 mAh\n\n\nCameras: 50-MP main camera, 10-MP telephoto (3X), 12-MP ultrawide, 10-MP front camera, 4-MP inner selfie camera\n\n\nUpdates (from date of manufacture): 7 years\n\n\nExtras: IPX8, fingerprint sensor, NFC, wireless charging\n\n\nCarrier compatibility: Works on all three major US networks","offers":[{"@type":"Offer","name":"Galaxy Z Fold6","price":"1900","priceCurrency":"USD","url":"https://www.amazon.com/SAMSUNG-Smartphone-Handsfree-Interpreter-Manufacturer/dp/B0D18VM66K","offeredBy":{"@type":"Organization","name":"Amazon"}},{"@type":"Offer","name":"Galaxy Z Fold6","price":"1900","priceCurrency":"USD","url":"https://www.samsung.com/us/smartphones/galaxy-z-fold6/buy/galaxy-z-fold6-256gb-unlocked-sm-f956uakaxaa/","offeredBy":{"@type":"Organization","name":"Samsung"}},{"@type":"Offer","name":"Galaxy Z Fold6","price":"1600","priceCurrency":"USD","url":"https://www.bestbuy.com/site/samsung-galaxy-z-fold6-256gb-unlocked-silver-shadow/6586750.p?skuId=6586750","offeredBy":{"@type":"Organization","name":"Best Buy"}}]}},{"@context":"https://schema.org","@type":"ListItem","position":8,"item":{"@type":"Product","name":"Galaxy S24, S24+, and S24 Ultra","brand":{"@type":"Brand","name":"Samsung"},"url":"https://www.wired.com/gallery/best-samsung-phones/#65b9593057a75cccd4844fc1","image":["https://media.wired.com/photos/65b98da33bb22b6581ebf4a7/4:3/w_960,c_limit/Gear-Samsung-Galaxy-S24-lineup-SOURCE-Julian-Chokkattu.jpg"],"description":"There's nothing wrong with buying last year's flagship phone. You often can score a good deal, especially on the used marketplace, and frankly, the Galaxy S24 series (8/10, WIRED Recommends) is shockingly identical to the latest Galaxy S25 devices. There's the 6.2-inch Galaxy S24, 6.7-inch Galaxy S24+, and 6.8-inch Galaxy S24 Ultra. They're powerful through and through, though they get a little warm and may not deliver as smooth gameplay in intensive games as much as the newer Galaxy S25 series. (Performance is otherwise pretty flawless.) I break down each of these devices even further here if you're stumped on which one to get. GalleryPageChunkRow-eNGlGj bhvZSw"><div class="GridWrapper-cAzTTK iBVjDs grid grid-margins grid-items-2 grid-layout--adrail narrow"><div class="GridItem-buujkM stRKV grid--item grid-layout__content"><div class="sticky-box__gallery-anchor-top"><div class="GalleryPageTextBlock-lkymFq gMkDtX"><div class="BodyWrapper-kufPGa erMawQ body GalleryPageIntroBody-jRNmRA jMjmeK body__container" data-journey-hook="client-content" data-testid="BodyWrapper"><div><p><span class="lead-in-text-callout">There's the iPhone,</span> and then there are Galaxy phones. Whereas Apple is <a href="https://www.wired.com/gallery/iphone-buying-guide/">the sole company</a> behind the iOS mobile operating system, even the best Samsung phones face stiff competition in the Android world. (And yes, <a href="https://www.wired.com/gallery/best-android-phones/">Galaxy phones <em>are</em> Android phones</a>, though Samsung calls its layer over Android “One UI.”)</p><p>Google's <a href="https://www.wired.com/story/best-google-pixel-phone/">Pixel phones</a> are my favorite <a href="https://www.wired.com/gallery/best-android-phones/">Android phones</a>, but Samsung devices are just as great and often have better hardware. Alongside Google, it has the longest software support for its <a href="https://www.wired.com/review/samsung-galaxy-a26-and-galaxy-a36/">cheap</a> <em>and</em> high-end devices. That means you don't have to upgrade your phone as often, as it will stay up-to-date, secure, and free of bugs for longer. But the Korean giant has many, many models at varying prices. What's the best Samsung phone? I sort it out here, starting with the <a data-offer-url="https://www.amazon.com/SAMSUNG-Smartphone-Unlocked-Processor-ProScaler/dp/B0DP3DB4CW?th=1" class="external-link" data-event-click="{"element":"ExternalLink","outgoingURL":"https://cna.st/affiliate-link/7c68xnGyocNZTFZuQWSTdKZqy9Ur8Csmk6Vb9e4T68ohwAEujSBhnQpj4L5TpiSV8x6QCCZWyLYhKY3M4KQUsUNNnXN531VKYEYA1JuVnaJk6KfehahtmutLcygFUvyWihjUmNpCwqQtQNr7RbVcqsVkG6osBoUboiiCMC5Yjd1thSgJLcuwgSbsqsw1eRZLffC3sZtnqhrdcoaWL9JSu7HSzswt"}" href="https://cna.st/affiliate-link/7c68xnGyocNZTFZuQWSTdKZqy9Ur8Csmk6Vb9e4T68ohwAEujSBhnQpj4L5TpiSV8x6QCCZWyLYhKY3M4KQUsUNNnXN531VKYEYA1JuVnaJk6KfehahtmutLcygFUvyWihjUmNpCwqQtQNr7RbVcqsVkG6osBoUboiiCMC5Yjd1thSgJLcuwgSbsqsw1eRZLffC3sZtnqhrdcoaWL9JSu7HSzswt" rel="sponsored" target="_blank" data-aps-asin="B0DP3DB4CW" data-aps-asc-tag="wirednl-20">Galaxy S25</a>. I also have tips and tricks to get the most out of your shiny new hardware.</p><p>Check out our mobile guides, including the <a href="https://www.wired.com/gallery/best-samsung-galaxy-s25-cases-and-accessories/">Best Samsung Galaxy S25 Cases</a>, <a href="https://www.wired.com/gallery/best-samsung-galaxy-s24-cases-and-accessories/">Best Galaxy S24 Cases</a>, <a href="https://www.wired.com/gallery/best-android-phones/">Best Android Phones</a>, <a href="https://www.wired.com/story/best-cheap-phones/">Best Cheap Phones</a>, <a href="https://www.wired.com/story/best-google-pixel-phone/">Best Pixel Phones</a>, and <a href="https://www.wired.com/gallery/best-folding-phones/">Best Folding Phones</a>.</p><native-ad position="in-content" shouldDisplayLabel="true"></native-ad><p><em>Updated June 2025: We've added the Galaxy S25 Edge, Galaxy A16, Galaxy A26, and Galaxy A36. We've also added details about the upcoming Galaxy Z Fold7 and Flip7.</em></p><div name="accordion" class="AccordionWrapper-hIuJtK bCzlaC"><div class="AccordionItemWrapper-eGPSID czXIDr"><div class="AccordionContainer-fEnXXG iiuTyf"><div data-testid="accordion-item-container" class="AccordionItemContainer-jbkqX ckSoPI"><div class="AccordionItemContainerLabel-hZxKcV bwkkoI"><p><strong>Why Buy Samsung?</strong></p></div><button class="BaseButton-bLlsy ButtonWrapper-xCepQ fhIjxp fCyinQ button button--utility AccordionItemContainerButton-eCWroF XOSgO" data-event-click="{"element":"Button"}" data-testid="Button" role="button" type="button"><span class="ButtonLabel-cjAuJN bBWXSg button__label">AccordionItemContainerButton</span><div class="ButtonIconWrapper-gFdzAL bPDyTT button__icon-container"><svg class="ButtonIcon-YqaGo iwlhuX button-icon icon icon-large-chevron" focusable="false" width="32" height="32" viewBox="0 0 32 32" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg"><title>LargeChevron</title><path fill-rule="evenodd" clip-rule="evenodd" d="m1.47 10.53 1.06-1.06L16 22.94 29.47 9.47l1.06 1.06L16 25.06 1.47 10.53Z" fill="#000"></path></svg></div></button></div><div class="AccordionItemContainerContent-cezZtS fKNdmR opening-animation"><div><p>The best part of being in the world of Android is choice of hardware. Want a phone with a headphone jack? <a href="https://www.wired.com/gallery/best-headphone-jack-phones/">Sure</a>! Want a gaming phone with two USB-C ports? <a href="https://www.wired.com/story/asus-rog-phone-9-series/">Why not</a>. Want a phone that fast-charges in around 30 minutes? <a href="https://www.wired.com/review/oneplus-13-and-oneplus-13r/">It exists</a>. So why stick with the stalwart Samsung?</p><p>In my experience and research, Samsung's smartphones have a track record of reliability, and because it's a major player, it has a wider network of authorized repair centers than competing Android manufacturers. Yes, I remember the <a href="https://www.wired.com/story/samsung-galaxy-note-7-battery-problems-result/">Galaxy Note 7 fiasco</a> and even the issues with the <a href="https://www.wired.com/story/the-galaxy-fold-has-been-fixed/">first-gen Galaxy Fold</a>, but Samsung now has a customer satisfaction score equal to Apple, according to <a data-offer-url="https://theacsi.org/industries/manufacturing/cell-phones/#samsung" class="external-link" data-event-click="{"element":"ExternalLink","outgoingURL":"https://theacsi.org/industries/manufacturing/cell-phones/#samsung"}" href="https://theacsi.org/industries/manufacturing/cell-phones/#samsung" rel="nofollow" target="_blank">the American Customer Satisfaction Index</a>. That said, I haven't read great things about the company's US customer support team.</p><p>With its flagship phones, you're getting top-of-the-line specs and exceptional build quality with long software support. I primarily pick Pixel phones over Samsung because I prefer Google's software experience, but there are plenty of people who like Samsung's take on Android. As always, keep an open mind and consider all the other options available to you.</p></div></div></div></div><div class="AccordionItemWrapper-eGPSID czXIDr"><div class="AccordionContainer-fEnXXG iiuTyf"><div data-testid="accordion-item-container" class="AccordionItemContainer-jbkqX ckSoPI"><div class="AccordionItemContainerLabel-hZxKcV bwkkoI"><p><strong>Is Now the Best Time to Buy?</strong></p></div><button class="BaseButton-bLlsy ButtonWrapper-xCepQ fhIjxp fCyinQ button button--utility AccordionItemContainerButton-eCWroF XOSgO" data-event-click="{"element":"Button"}" data-testid="Button" role="button" type="button"><span class="ButtonLabel-cjAuJN bBWXSg button__label">AccordionItemContainerButton</span><div class="ButtonIconWrapper-gFdzAL bPDyTT button__icon-container"><svg class="ButtonIcon-YqaGo iwlhuX button-icon icon icon-large-chevron" focusable="false" width="32" height="32" viewBox="0 0 32 32" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg"><title>LargeChevron</title><path fill-rule="evenodd" clip-rule="evenodd" d="m1.47 10.53 1.06-1.06L16 22.94 29.47 9.47l1.06 1.06L16 25.06 1.47 10.53Z" fill="#000"></path></svg></div></button></div><div class="AccordionItemContainerContent-cezZtS fKNdmR opening-animation"><div><p>Samsung's Galaxy S25 series arrived early in the year, meaning if you want a new flagship, it's a great time to buy. It also has debuted most of its budget phones for 2025, so if money's tight, you have a new options to consider. However, it's worth keeping the company's launch time frames in mind if you <em>only</em> want the latest and greatest.</p><ul><li><strong>The flagship Galaxy S series</strong> launches at the start of the year during Samsung's Galaxy Unpacked event. The Galaxy S25 series, for example, was announced on January 22 and launched on February 7.</li><li><strong>The budget Galaxy A series</strong> typically arrives in the spring (April or May). There are several A series phones so they usually dribble out during the first few months of the year. This year, there's the Galaxy A16, A26, A36, and A56. The A56 has not launched yet in the US.</li><li><strong>The folding Galaxy Z series</strong> have always launched in the summer, and this year's event is coming up this July during Samsung's second and last Galaxy Unpacked of the year. I would hold off on buying a folding Samsung phone until then.</li><li><strong>The midrange Galaxy FE series</strong> is the “Fan Edition,” but this is more or less a slightly cheaper variant of the Galaxy S series. It typically launches in the fall, around late September or October.</li></ul><p>Consider these dates as you shop, because you may want to hold off and wait for the new model, or it can help inform you on when to expect the best discounts.</p></div></div></div></div><div class="AccordionItemWrapper-eGPSID czXIDr"><div class="AccordionContainer-fEnXXG iiuTyf"><div data-testid="accordion-item-container" class="AccordionItemContainer-jbkqX ckSoPI"><div class="AccordionItemContainerLabel-hZxKcV bwkkoI"><p><strong>How Long Are Samsung Phones Supported?</strong></p></div><button class="BaseButton-bLlsy ButtonWrapper-xCepQ fhIjxp fCyinQ button button--utility AccordionItemContainerButton-eCWroF XOSgO" data-event-click="{"element":"Button"}" data-testid="Button" role="button" type="button"><span class="ButtonLabel-cjAuJN bBWXSg button__label">AccordionItemContainerButton</span><div class="ButtonIconWrapper-gFdzAL bPDyTT button__icon-container"><svg class="ButtonIcon-YqaGo iwlhuX button-icon icon icon-large-chevron" focusable="false" width="32" height="32" viewBox="0 0 32 32" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg"><title>LargeChevron</title><path fill-rule="evenodd" clip-rule="evenodd" d="m1.47 10.53 1.06-1.06L16 22.94 29.47 9.47l1.06 1.06L16 25.06 1.47 10.53Z" fill="#000"></path></svg></div></button></div><div class="AccordionItemContainerContent-cezZtS fKNdmR opening-animation"><div><p>Android phones used to have disastrously <a href="https://www.wired.com/story/phone-ios-android-security-updates/">poor software support</a>. Two years after you bought your $1,000 phone, it would no longer receive software updates. Thankfully, Google began promising longer software update cycles to its <a href="https://www.wired.com/story/best-google-pixel-phone/">Pixel phones</a>, which ended up pushing Samsung to match it.</p><p>The following Samsung phones will receive <strong>seven</strong> <strong>years of software updates</strong> from their release date, which includes Android operating system updates and monthly security patches. The latter keep your phone secure, and new OS versions can bring <a href="https://www.wired.com/story/how-to-download-android-15-and-features/">new features</a> to your phone.</p><ul><li>Galaxy S25, Galaxy S25+, Galaxy S25 Edge, and Galaxy S25 Ultra</li><li>Galaxy S24, Galaxy S24+, and Galaxy S24 Ultra</li><li>Galaxy Z Fold6 and Galaxy Z Flip6</li><li>Galaxy S24 FE</li></ul><p>Samsung's latest Galaxy A-series phones, from the A16 and up, will receive 6 years of updates. Most other older Samsung devices, like some in the Galaxy A series or older flagships, will receive four years of OS updates and five years of security patches starting from the date of release. Some of this varies, as Samsung has kept changing its policy year over year, but there's <a data-offer-url="https://r2.community.samsung.com/t5/Galaxy-A/%EF%B8%8FOS-update-Policy-By-Samsung-%EF%B8%8F-as-of-Jan-2024/td-p/16170439" class="external-link" data-event-click="{"element":"ExternalLink","outgoingURL":"https://r2.community.samsung.com/t5/Galaxy-A/%EF%B8%8FOS-update-Policy-By-Samsung-%EF%B8%8F-as-of-Jan-2024/td-p/16170439"}" href="https://r2.community.samsung.com/t5/Galaxy-A/%EF%B8%8FOS-update-Policy-By-Samsung-%EF%B8%8F-as-of-Jan-2024/td-p/16170439" rel="nofollow" target="_blank">a little more helpful information here</a>.</p><p>To find if your Samsung phone has a pending update, go to <strong>Settings > Software update > Download and install</strong>. It should check for any updates and download them, then you'll see an option to install it. Make sure you back up your phone before installing any update. We <a href="https://www.wired.com/story/how-to-backup-your-android/#samsung">have a guide here</a>.</p></div></div></div></div><div class="AccordionItemWrapper-eGPSID czXIDr"><div class="AccordionContainer-fEnXXG iiuTyf"><div data-testid="accordion-item-container" class="AccordionItemContainer-jbkqX ckSoPI"><div class="AccordionItemContainerLabel-hZxKcV bwkkoI"><p><strong>Why I Recommend Buying Unlocked</strong></p></div><button class="BaseButton-bLlsy ButtonWrapper-xCepQ fhIjxp fCyinQ button button--utility AccordionItemContainerButton-eCWroF XOSgO" data-event-click="{"element":"Button"}" data-testid="Button" role="button" type="button"><span class="ButtonLabel-cjAuJN bBWXSg button__label">AccordionItemContainerButton</span><div class="ButtonIconWrapper-gFdzAL bPDyTT button__icon-container"><svg class="ButtonIcon-YqaGo iwlhuX button-icon icon icon-large-chevron" focusable="false" width="32" height="32" viewBox="0 0 32 32" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg"><title>LargeChevron</title><path fill-rule="evenodd" clip-rule="evenodd" d="m1.47 10.53 1.06-1.06L16 22.94 29.47 9.47l1.06 1.06L16 25.06 1.47 10.53Z" fill="#000"></path></svg></div></button></div><div class="AccordionItemContainerContent-cezZtS fKNdmR opening-animation"><div><p>Most people buy phones directly from their carrier, but if you're reading this guide, I suggest you buy an unlocked smartphone. When you buy a carrier phone, it's “<a href="https://arstechnica.com/tech-policy/2024/10/t-mobile-att-oppose-unlocking-rule-claim-locked-phones-are-good-for-users/">locked</a>” to that network. That means if you want to switch carriers, like move from Verizon to T-Mobile, you'll have to ask your carrier to unlock the device, and this can be a huge headache. (Especially if you're traveling and want to use an <a href="https://www.wired.com/story/how-to-use-buy-esim-international-travel-trips/">international SIM card</a>.) Asking a carrier to unlock a phone usually has a few requirements, like making sure your device is paid off, or waiting for a set period of time. Unlocked phones, on the other hand, don't have this problem. You're free to use whatever carrier you want, whenever.</p><p>Carriers also mask the true cost of a smartphone. AT&T may entice you with a $36 per month payment for a shiny new Samsung flagship, when in reality, that means you're paying $1,300 on a smartphone over 36 months. Did you really want to spend <em>that much</em>? Or will a cheaper phone suffice? Also, you're more likely to get software updates faster as they come directly from Samsung, and there's often far less preinstalled bloatware to deal with.</p><p>All to say, buy unlocked! You can buy unlocked Galaxy phones directly from Samsung and most third-party retailers like Amazon, Best Buy, and Walmart.</p></div></div></div></div><div class="AccordionItemWrapper-eGPSID czXIDr"><div class="AccordionContainer-fEnXXG iiuTyf"><div data-testid="accordion-item-container" class="AccordionItemContainer-jbkqX ckSoPI"><div class="AccordionItemContainerLabel-hZxKcV bwkkoI"><p><strong>The Settings to Change on Your New Samsung Phone</strong></p></div><button class="BaseButton-bLlsy ButtonWrapper-xCepQ fhIjxp fCyinQ button button--utility AccordionItemContainerButton-eCWroF XOSgO" data-event-click="{"element":"Button"}" data-testid="Button" role="button" type="button"><span class="ButtonLabel-cjAuJN bBWXSg button__label">AccordionItemContainerButton</span><div class="ButtonIconWrapper-gFdzAL bPDyTT button__icon-container"><svg class="ButtonIcon-YqaGo iwlhuX button-icon icon icon-large-chevron" focusable="false" width="32" height="32" viewBox="0 0 32 32" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg"><title>LargeChevron</title><path fill-rule="evenodd" clip-rule="evenodd" d="m1.47 10.53 1.06-1.06L16 22.94 29.47 9.47l1.06 1.06L16 25.06 1.47 10.53Z" fill="#000"></path></svg></div></button></div><div class="AccordionItemContainerContent-cezZtS fKNdmR opening-animation"><div><p>Samsung has an annoying habit of announcing a bunch of cool new features with its smartphones, then leaving them turned off by default. If you've never fiddled around with your phone's settings, there's a good chance there are a <em>lot</em> of fun and helpful features you're not using.</p><p>This can include things like changing the navigation from on-screen buttons to gesture navigation, adding the battery percentage icon next to the battery bar, or keeping the always-on display turned on instead of requiring a tap on the screen. Good news for you! As I routinely switch phones, I drummed up a list of the most important settings to change when you get a Samsung phone. <strong><a href="https://www.wired.com/story/key-settings-to-change-on-samsung-galaxy-phones/">Read it here</a>.</strong> Pro tip: I personally can't stand using Samsung's default keyboard, so I almost always change it to <a href="https://play.google.com/store/apps/details?id=com.google.android.inputmethod.latin&hl=en_US">Google's Gboard instead</a>.</p><div class="ContentCardEmbedWrapper-kULtsE iGAJsG content-card-embed content-card-embed--stacked" data-testid="ContentCardEmbedWrapper"><div class="ContentCardEmbedImage-iwqgVw jlIubp content-card-embed__image" data-testid="ContentCardEmbedImage"><span class="SpanWrapper-umhxW cudDwW responsive-asset"><picture class="ResponsiveImagePicture-cWuUZO dUOtEa responsive-image"><img alt="Left: The camera side of a Samsung Galaxy S25 beside S25 Plus phone showing the screen. Right: Rear view of a Samsung Galaxy S25 Ultra, showing the cameras and stylus. Background: pink and yellow cosmic gel. " class="ResponsiveImageContainer-eybHBd fptoWY responsive-image__image" src="https://media.wired.com/photos/67ad065f8acc56742534fce2/master/w_775%2Cc_limit/Samsung-Settings-to-Change-on-Your-New-Galaxy-Phone-Reviewer-Collage-022025-SOURCE-Julian-Chokkattu.jpg" srcSet="https://media.wired.com/photos/67ad065f8acc56742534fce2/master/w_120,c_limit/Samsung-Settings-to-Change-on-Your-New-Galaxy-Phone-Reviewer-Collage-022025-SOURCE-Julian-Chokkattu.jpg 120w, https://media.wired.com/photos/67ad065f8acc56742534fce2/master/w_240,c_limit/Samsung-Settings-to-Change-on-Your-New-Galaxy-Phone-Reviewer-Collage-022025-SOURCE-Julian-Chokkattu.jpg 240w, https://media.wired.com/photos/67ad065f8acc56742534fce2/master/w_320,c_limit/Samsung-Settings-to-Change-on-Your-New-Galaxy-Phone-Reviewer-Collage-022025-SOURCE-Julian-Chokkattu.jpg 320w, https://media.wired.com/photos/67ad065f8acc56742534fce2/master/w_640,c_limit/Samsung-Settings-to-Change-on-Your-New-Galaxy-Phone-Reviewer-Collage-022025-SOURCE-Julian-Chokkattu.jpg 640w" sizes="100vw"/></picture></span></div><div class="ContentCardEmbedInfo-bDftKl bGnSrq"><div class="BaseWrap-sc-gjQpdd BaseText-ewhhUZ ContentCardEmbedHed-kJVPGC iUEiRd cekThb cewqFA content-card-embed__hed" data-testid="ContentCardEmbedHed"><a class="BaseWrap-sc-gjQpdd BaseText-ewhhUZ BaseLink-eNWuiM ContentCardEmbedHedLink-eXLwe iUEiRd cekThb gqhxzW eFUKSb content-card-embed__hed-link" href="/story/key-settings-to-change-on-samsung-galaxy-phones/" data-testid="ContentCardEmbedHedLink">All the Settings You Should Change on Your New Samsung Phone</a></div><div data-testid="ContentCardEmbedDek" class="ContentCardEmbedDek-bA-DKch cNHfUN">There are too many great features turned off by default. Rectify that with these tips.</div><div data-testid="BylinesWrapper" class="BylinesWrapper-KIudk cdSbAY bylines"><span class="BylineWrapper-jWHrLH eedAre byline bylines__byline" data-testid="BylineWrapper" itemProp="author" itemType="http://schema.org/Person"><span itemProp="name" class="BylineNamesWrapper-jbHncj fuDQVo"><span data-testid="BylineName" class="BylineName-kwmrLn cYaBcc byline__name"><span class="BaseWrap-sc-gjQpdd BaseText-ewhhUZ BylinePreamble-iJolpQ iUEiRd bsrfLw gnILss byline__preamble">By </span><a class="BaseWrap-sc-gjQpdd BaseText-ewhhUZ BaseLink-eNWuiM BylineLink-gEnFiw iUEiRd euNVPR jdMSdZ eErqIx byline__name-link button" href="/author/julian-chokkattu/">Julian Chokkattu</a></span></span></span></div></div></div></div></div></div></div><div class="AccordionItemWrapper-eGPSID czXIDr"><div class="AccordionContainer-fEnXXG iiuTyf"><div data-testid="accordion-item-container" class="AccordionItemContainer-jbkqX ckSoPI"><div class="AccordionItemContainerLabel-hZxKcV bwkkoI"><p><strong>Explaining the Galaxy S25 and Qi2</strong></p></div><button class="BaseButton-bLlsy ButtonWrapper-xCepQ fhIjxp fCyinQ button button--utility AccordionItemContainerButton-eCWroF XOSgO" data-event-click="{"element":"Button"}" data-testid="Button" role="button" type="button"><span class="ButtonLabel-cjAuJN bBWXSg button__label">AccordionItemContainerButton</span><div class="ButtonIconWrapper-gFdzAL bPDyTT button__icon-container"><svg class="ButtonIcon-YqaGo iwlhuX button-icon icon icon-large-chevron" focusable="false" width="32" height="32" viewBox="0 0 32 32" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg"><title>LargeChevron</title><path fill-rule="evenodd" clip-rule="evenodd" d="m1.47 10.53 1.06-1.06L16 22.94 29.47 9.47l1.06 1.06L16 25.06 1.47 10.53Z" fill="#000"></path></svg></div></button></div><div class="AccordionItemContainerContent-cezZtS fKNdmR opening-animation"><div><p>Qi2 is the new wireless charging standard—it takes a page from Apple's <a href="https://www.wired.com/gallery/best-magsafe-accessories/">MagSafe technology</a> and embeds magnets directly into the smartphone, allowing it to connect to accessories and chargers magnetically, even the same ones available for iPhones. That has the potential to increase the compatibility of accessories across devices, which is a good thing. The magnets ensure precise charging, so you never worry about a misaligned phone that won't charge, it offers better efficiency, and can potentially charge faster. We have more details in our <a href="https://www.wired.com/story/what-is-qi2-wireless-charging/">Qi2 explainer here</a>.</p><p>Confusingly, Samsung's newest flagship phones are “<strong>Qi2 Ready</strong>” and technically not true Qi2 smartphones. This means that they have the capability to support Qi2 if paired with a <a href="https://www.wired.com/story/android-magsafe-pixel-samsung-peak-design-everyday-case/">magnetic case</a>, but alone, the S25 series do not have built-in magnets. It's disappointing and creates more confusion, and already I've encountered some cases with varying degrees of magnetic strength, and some cases don't quite work with basic <a href="https://www.wired.com/gallery/best-wireless-chargers/">Qi wireless charging stands</a>. Read our <a href="https://www.wired.com/story/qi2-ready-certified-phones-and-cases/">deep dive into "Qi2 Ready"</a> for more. And check out our <a href="https://www.wired.com/gallery/best-samsung-galaxy-s25-cases-and-accessories/">Best Galaxy S25 Cases guide too</a>.</p></div></div></div></div><div class="AccordionItemWrapper-eGPSID czXIDr"><div class="AccordionContainer-fEnXXG iiuTyf"><div data-testid="accordion-item-container" class="AccordionItemContainer-jbkqX ckSoPI"><div class="AccordionItemContainerLabel-hZxKcV bwkkoI"><p>Qualcomm Snapdragon vs. Exynos Chipsets</p></div><button class="BaseButton-bLlsy ButtonWrapper-xCepQ fhIjxp fCyinQ button button--utility AccordionItemContainerButton-eCWroF XOSgO" data-event-click="{"element":"Button"}" data-testid="Button" role="button" type="button"><span class="ButtonLabel-cjAuJN bBWXSg button__label">AccordionItemContainerButton</span><div class="ButtonIconWrapper-gFdzAL bPDyTT button__icon-container"><svg class="ButtonIcon-YqaGo iwlhuX button-icon icon icon-large-chevron" focusable="false" width="32" height="32" viewBox="0 0 32 32" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg"><title>LargeChevron</title><path fill-rule="evenodd" clip-rule="evenodd" d="m1.47 10.53 1.06-1.06L16 22.94 29.47 9.47l1.06 1.06L16 25.06 1.47 10.53Z" fill="#000"></path></svg></div></button></div><div class="AccordionItemContainerContent-cezZtS fKNdmR opening-animation"><div><p>A Samsung phone sold in the US may not be the same as a Samsung phone sold in the UK. That's because Samsung's Galaxy S series flagship phones have long relied on two different processors. Devices sold in the US and select markets are powered by Qualcomm's Snapdragon processors, whereas other regions have Samsung's homegrown Exynos chipsets. Recently, Samsung has opted to use Qualcomm chips globally, though even in the US, some cheaper Samsung phones employ Exynos.</p><p>The gap isn't as wide between these processors anymore, but there have been issues in the past. Exynos chips tended to overheat a few years ago, though they sometimes offer slightly better battery life than their Qualcomm counterparts. It even greatly impacted camera quality too as the chip handles the image processing. Again, none of this is <em>as</em> big of an issue as it used to be, but it's worth keeping in mind as you shop.</p></div></div></div></div></div></div></div></div><ul class="GalleryPageSlides-hIivta gKmvyw"><li class="gallery__slides__slide" id="67a4570388c8f13c80c0c157"><div><div class="UnifiedProductCardBody-hDFFwy jmjUSU product-embed impressionTracking" data-item="{"ctaAnalyticsName":"buy-button-click","bookmarkMeta":{"slug":"gallery/best-samsung-phones","title":"The Best Samsung Phones"},"brand":{"name":"Samsung"},"contentType":"product","ctaHref":null,"dangerousCredit":"","dangerousHed":"The Best Samsung Phone(s)","dek":["div",["p","The first place to start when considering a Samsung phone is the Galaxy S25 series (",["a",{"href":"https://www.wired.com/review/samsung-galaxy-s25-s25-plus-and-s25-ultra","isExternal":false},"7/10, WIRED Recommends"],"), the company's ",["a",{"href":"https://www.wired.com/story/samsung-galaxy-s25-galaxy-s25-plus-galaxy-s25-ultra/","isExternal":false},"current flagship lineup"],". Not much has changed from its predecessors (seriously, many of the specs are identical), but that doesn't stop them from being excellent and reliable smartphones. The Galaxy S25 is the smallest of the lot with a 6.2-inch screen, and then there's the Galaxy S25+ at 6.7 inches—choosing between them largely depends on whether you want a small, pocketable phone or a big display. There are ",["a",{"href":"https://www.wired.com/story/which-samsung-galaxy-s24-model-to-buy/","isExternal":false},"minuscule differences in some specs"],", such as how the S25+ comes with 256 GB of storage, and the bigger size means a beefier battery, but they're more alike than ever before."],["p","You get every high-end feature you can think of, from UFS 4.0 storage speeds to brilliantly bright AMOLED displays with high ",["a",{"href":"https://www.wired.com/story/high-refresh-rate-explained/","isExternal":false},"120-Hz refresh rates"]," that ratchet down to 1 Hz to be more energy efficient. The batteries typically last a full day of average use with around 30 to 40 percent left, and there's an excellent triple-camera system with 3x optical zoom, an ultrawide in addition to the main camera, and a strong selfie shooter. These phones also put out some of the best video footage out of the box, so they're great for budding TikTokkers. Arguably, the most notable improvement over prior models is performance—the efficient Snapdragon 8 Elite chipset paired with Samsung's improved cooling technology means it can handle demanding games like ",["em","Genshin Impact"]," with fewer stutters and without getting warm too quickly. I'm not fond of the design—they're a bit bland—but at least you can snag them in some unique colors exclusive to ",["a",{"href":"https://cna.st/affiliate-link/FX1LF4r6izvTB7YiWdVoZ7S2QMwao23jxfFAdUSPtgqweFBaeVLB29NYLDpNVmEvt9ft1YkCvFhApvwAmpWkjypAW5nABRbCJ2KWpe2ih7XizqQXihWcu9HZdNh3MC6C9bKKoi9Rk7ufo6gSu5XhPxqqXJAwDq5cn17AiEEFbwYUBSqCNxUiJEsBwA1cNyJQth9mGB8wBnn7SnfwMpeQp3QAHfynUzF7zW7x","rel":"sponsored","isaffiliatelink":"true","attributes":{"data-offer-url":"https://www.samsung.com/us/smartphones/galaxy-s25/buy/galaxy-s25-128gb-unlocked-sm-s931uzraxaa/"},"isExternal":true},"Samsung.com"],"."],["p","Samsung focused on several Galaxy AI features in this release, like making Google's Gemini the default voice assistant when you press and hold the power button. Gemini can now integrate with multiple apps—native Samsung and Google apps—so you can ask it to find the games for your favorite basketball team and add them to your calendar. S25 series (<a href="https://www.wired.com/review/samsung-galaxy-s25-s25-plus-and-s25-ultra">7/10, WIRED Recommends</a>), the company's <a href="https://www.wired.com/story/samsung-galaxy-s25-galaxy-s25-plus-galaxy-s25-ultra/">current flagship lineup</a>. Not much has changed from its predecessors (seriously, many of the specs are identical), but that doesn't stop them from being excellent and reliable smartphones. The Galaxy S25 is the smallest of the lot with a 6.2-inch screen, and then there's the Galaxy S25+ at 6.7 inches—choosing between them largely depends on whether you want a small, pocketable phone or a big display. There are <a href="https://www.wired.com/story/which-samsung-galaxy-s24-model-to-buy/">minuscule differences in some specs</a>, such as how the S25+ comes with 256 GB of storage, and the bigger size means a beefier battery, but they're more alike than ever before.</p><p>You get every high-end feature you can think of, from UFS 4.0 storage speeds to brilliantly bright AMOLED displays with high <a href="https://www.wired.com/story/high-refresh-rate-explained/">120-Hz refresh rates</a> that ratchet down to 1 Hz to be more energy efficient. The batteries typically last a full day of average use with around 30 to 40 percent left, and there's an excellent triple-camera system with 3x optical zoom, an ultrawide in addition to the main camera, and a strong selfie shooter. These phones also put out some of the best video footage out of the box, so they're great for budding TikTokkers. Arguably, the most notable improvement over prior models is performance—the efficient Snapdragon 8 Elite chipset paired with Samsung's improved cooling technology means it can handle demanding games like <em>Genshin Impact</em> with fewer stutters and without getting warm too quickly. I'm not fond of the design—they're a bit bland—but at least you can snag them in some unique colors exclusive to <a data-offer-url="https://www.samsung.com/us/smartphones/galaxy-s25/buy/galaxy-s25-128gb-unlocked-sm-s931uzraxaa/" class="external-link" data-event-click="{"element":"ExternalLink","outgoingURL":"https://cna.st/affiliate-link/FX1LF4r6izvTB7YiWdVoZ7S2QMwao23jxfFAdUSPtgqweFBaeVLB29NYLDpNVmEvt9ft1YkCvFhApvwAmpWkjypAW5nABRbCJ2KWpe2ih7XizqQXihWcu9HZdNh3MC6C9bKKoi9Rk7ufo6gSu5XhPxqqXJAwDq5cn17AiEEFbwYUBSqCNxUiJEsBwA1cNyJQth9mGB8wBnn7SnfwMpeQp3QAHfynUzF7zW7x"}" href="https://cna.st/affiliate-link/FX1LF4r6izvTB7YiWdVoZ7S2QMwao23jxfFAdUSPtgqweFBaeVLB29NYLDpNVmEvt9ft1YkCvFhApvwAmpWkjypAW5nABRbCJ2KWpe2ih7XizqQXihWcu9HZdNh3MC6C9bKKoi9Rk7ufo6gSu5XhPxqqXJAwDq5cn17AiEEFbwYUBSqCNxUiJEsBwA1cNyJQth9mGB8wBnn7SnfwMpeQp3QAHfynUzF7zW7x" rel="sponsored" target="_blank">Samsung.com</a>.</p><p>Samsung focused on several Galaxy AI features in this release, like making Google's Gemini the default voice assistant when you press and hold the power button. Gemini can now integrate with multiple apps—native Samsung and Google apps—so you can ask it to find the games for your favorite basketball team and add them to your calendar. Some of these AI features, <a href="https://www.wired.com/story/samsung-galaxy-s25-galaxy-s25-plus-galaxy-s25-ultra/" target="_blank">outlined here</a>, are helpful, while others, like Now Brief, are not.</p><table><thead><tr><th>Specs: Galaxy S25</th><th>Galaxy S25+</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td><strong>Display:</strong> 6.2 inches, 120-Hz LTPO, AMOLED</td><td>6.7 inches, 120-Hz LTPO, AMOLED</td></tr><tr><td><strong>Processor and RAM:</strong> Qualcomm Snapdragon 8 Elite with 12 GB of RAM</td><td>Qualcomm Snapdragon 8 Elite with 12 GB of RAM</td></tr><tr><td><strong>Storage:</strong> 128, 256, and 512 GB</td><td>256 and 512 GB</td></tr><tr><td><strong>Battery:</strong> 4,000 mAh</td><td>4,900 mAh</td></tr><tr><td><strong>Cameras:</strong> 50-MP main camera, 12-MP ultrawide, 10-MP telephoto (3x), and 12-MP selfie camera</td><td>50-MP main camera, 12-MP ultrawide, 10-MP telephoto (3x), and 12-MP selfie camera</td></tr><tr><td><strong>Updates (from date of manufacture):</strong> 7 years</td><td>7 years</td></tr><tr><td><strong>Extras:</strong> Non-magnetic Qi 2.1 wireless charging (Qi2 Ready with case). That'd be the Galaxy S25 Ultra (",["a",{"href":"https://www.wired.com/review/samsung-galaxy-s25-s25-plus-and-s25-ultra","target":"_blank","isExternal":false},"7/10, WIRED Recommends"],"), though it doesn't feel as “ultra” as its predecessors. This phone shares many specs and features with the standard Galaxy S25 series—even the design is unified—but it has more durable front glass for better drop protection and scratch resistance, as well as a titanium frame. However, this doesn't mean it's less prone to breakage (use a case!). It's the biggest phone of the trio, meaning it has the largest battery, which can extend into the morning of a second day. Notably, the S25 Ultra has a built-in stylus—you pull it out from the bottom and start writing on the screen to jot down notes or doodle when bored on a Zoom call. Unfortunately, Samsung removed the ability to use it as a Bluetooth remote for the camera."],["p","Speaking of, the cameras are where it goes the extra mile—not only is the main camera a 200-megapixel shooter that can preserve more details, but there are also ",["em","two"]," telephoto cameras in addition to the new and improved 50-megapixel ultrawide. At 3x and 5x, you have better zoom options with great quality, though this starts to diminish in low light. (I do miss the 10x optical zoom from the ",["a",{"href":"https://www.wired.com/review/samsung-galaxy-s23-and-s23-ultra/","isExternal":false},"Galaxy S23"],".) The ultrawide also performs well in low light and has delivered sharper results than the Google Pixel 9 Pro and iPhone 16 Pro Max."],["p","But just because this is Samsung's top-of-the-line phone, it doesn't mean this is the right phone for you. class="UnifiedLandscapeProductCardDescDetails-OtRtu gwSJOK"><div class="BaseWrap-sc-gjQpdd BaseText-ewhhUZ UnifiedProductCardDescriptionWrapper-dDTcJP iUEiRd ikAILL dASmJi"><div><p>Want the best Samsung has to offer? That'd be the Galaxy S25 Ultra (<a href="https://www.wired.com/review/samsung-galaxy-s25-s25-plus-and-s25-ultra" target="_blank">7/10, WIRED Recommends</a>), though it doesn't feel as “ultra” as its predecessors. This phone shares many specs and features with the standard Galaxy S25 series—even the design is unified—but it has more durable front glass for better drop protection and scratch resistance, as well as a titanium frame. However, this doesn't mean it's less prone to breakage (use a case!). It's the biggest phone of the trio, meaning it has the largest battery, which can extend into the morning of a second day. Notably, the S25 Ultra has a built-in stylus—you pull it out from the bottom and start writing on the screen to jot down notes or doodle when bored on a Zoom call. Unfortunately, Samsung removed the ability to use it as a Bluetooth remote for the camera.</p><p>Speaking of, the cameras are where it goes the extra mile—not only is the main camera a 200-megapixel shooter that can preserve more details, but there are also <em>two</em> telephoto cameras in addition to the new and improved 50-megapixel ultrawide. At 3x and 5x, you have better zoom options with great quality, though this starts to diminish in low light. (I do miss the 10x optical zoom from the <a href="https://www.wired.com/review/samsung-galaxy-s23-and-s23-ultra/">Galaxy S23</a>.) The ultrawide also performs well in low light and has delivered sharper results than the Google Pixel 9 Pro and iPhone 16 Pro Max.</p><p>But just because this is Samsung's top-of-the-line phone, it doesn't mean this is the right phone for you. If you don't care about a stylus and don't use the zoom functions on a smartphone camera much, there are few reasons to spend so much on the S25 Ultra.</p><table><thead><tr><th>Specs</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td><strong>Display:</strong> 6.9 inches, 120-Hz LTPO, AMOLED</td></tr><tr><td><strong>Processor and RAM:</strong> Snapdragon 8 Elite with 12 GB RAM</td></tr><tr><td><strong>Storage:</strong> 256-GB, 512-GB, and 1-TB options</td></tr><tr><td><strong>Battery:</strong> 5,000 mAh</td></tr><tr><td><strong>Cameras:</strong> 200-MP main, 50-MP ultrawide, 10-MP telephoto (3X), 50-MP telephoto (5X), and 12-MP selfie camera</td></tr><tr><td><strong>Updates (from date of manufacture):</strong> 7 years</td></tr><tr><td><strong>Extras:</strong> Non-magnetic Qi 2.1 wireless charging (Qi2 Ready with case). IP68. S Pen stylus, fingerprint unlock, NFC, titanium frame, Gorilla Armor 2 front, Gorilla Glass Victus 2 rear</td></tr><tr><td><strong>Carrier compatibility:</strong> Works on all three major US networks</td></tr></tbody></table></div></div><div class="UnifiedProductCardReviewSection-epzOlN gUIihX"></div></div></div></div><div class="AdWrapper-dQtivb fZrssQ ad ad--in-content"><div class="ad__slot ad__slot--in-content" data-node-id="k4oiv7r" data-ad-index="0"></div></div></div></li></ul></div></div></div></div></div><div class="LazyChunk-lbwTjc cwDPsI"><div data-testid="RowWrapper" class="BaseWrap-sc-gjQpdd RowWrapper-UmqTg iUEiRd HEhan GalleryPageChunkRow-eNGlGj bhvZSw"><div class="GridWrapper-cAzTTK iBVjDs grid grid-margins grid-items-2 grid-layout--adrail narrow"><div class="GridItem-buujkM stRKV grid--item grid-layout__content"><div class=""><ul class="GalleryPageSlides-hIivta gKmvyw"><li class="gallery__slides__slide" id="67173b9472ffb317d7029ec4"><div><div class="UnifiedProductCardBody-hDFFwy jmjUSU product-embed impressionTracking" data-item="{"ctaAnalyticsName":"buy-button-click","bookmarkMeta":{"slug":"gallery/best-samsung-phones","title":"The Best Samsung Phones"},"brand":{"name":"Samsung"},"contentType":"product","ctaHref":null,"dangerousCredit":"","dangerousHed":"A Respectable Midrange Phone","dek":["div",["p","The Galaxy S24 FE brings the top-of-the-line features from last year's flagship, the ",["a",{"href":"https://www.wired.com/review/samsung-galaxy-s24-s24-plus-and-s24-ultra/","isExternal":false},"Galaxy S24"],", to a more palatable price. “FE” stands for Fan Edition, though this moniker never made much sense to me because wouldn't a Samsung fan want to save up for the flagship? In any case, the S24 FE is only worth buying if you can catch it on sale for around $500 or below—anything more, and you may as well buy a ",["a",{"href":"https://cna.st/affiliate-link/gVLYTFHP77FHrVD2wiD1iV9aSrS1tCMVhfYiXSeG72uHKkhBGw7QELC5gBBhV2h1qmjro6AKiz7K7gK7vgJaRoXN8AxJJ7GjncGos38BkxjHewt2K3YoEUeJAA1o7RBQaYxXkvyfU3FE5fon2qYPmSupzaBGay1ANvDddytmG2PLRvntf9bTmLP8RCCQnAzvsXjQ8WyU8ZnyBGnpvS","rel":"sponsored","isaffiliatelink":"true","attributes":{"data-offer-url":"https://www.amazon.com/SAMSUNG-Smartphone-Unlocked-Android-Processor/dp/B0CMDRCZBJ"},"isExternal":true},"Galaxy S24"]," (used or new), or wait for the Galaxy S25 to dip on sale."],["p","I used the S24 FE for close to a month and had a perfectly fine time with it. It uses Samsung's Exynos processor, and I haven't had any performance issues whatsoever; my benchmark scores put it a smidge below the Galaxy S24 and its Snapdragon chipset. You still get access to all the ",["a",{"href":"https://www.wired.com/story/samsung-galaxy-unpacked-2024/","isExternal":false},"original Galaxy AI features"],", nearly the same triple-camera experience, the 7-year software update policy, and perks like IP68 water resistance and wireless charging. What you miss out on are a higher resolution display, extra RAM, and more storage options. The bezels are a smidge thicker around the screen, which doesn't support LTPO (the ",["a",{"href":"https://www.wired.com/story/high-refresh-rate-explained/","isExternal":false},"tech that allows the display"]," to move from 1 Hz to 120 Hz to conserve battery life). The fingerprint scanner is also optical and not ultrasonic, and while it's been quite responsive for me, ultrasonic scanners are often more reliable. Battery life has been solid; after several weeks of use, I average 30 percent left in the tank by midnight, and that's with a few hours of GPS navigation and music streaming thrown in, not to mention too many hours of riffling through Instagram Reels."],["table",["thead",["tr",["th","Specs"]]],["tbody",["tr",["td",["strong","Display:"]," 6.7 inch, 120 Hz, AMOLED"]],["tr",["td",["strong","Processor class="BaseWrap-sc-gjQpdd BaseText-ewhhUZ UnifiedProductCardDescriptionWrapper-dDTcJP iUEiRd ikAILL dASmJi"><div><p>The Galaxy S24 FE brings the top-of-the-line features from last year's flagship, the <a href="https://www.wired.com/review/samsung-galaxy-s24-s24-plus-and-s24-ultra/">Galaxy S24</a>, to a more palatable price. “FE” stands for Fan Edition, though this moniker never made much sense to me because wouldn't a Samsung fan want to save up for the flagship? In any case, the S24 FE is only worth buying if you can catch it on sale for around $500 or below—anything more, and you may as well buy a <a data-offer-url="https://www.amazon.com/SAMSUNG-Smartphone-Unlocked-Android-Processor/dp/B0CMDRCZBJ" class="external-link" data-event-click="{"element":"ExternalLink","outgoingURL":"https://cna.st/affiliate-link/gVLYTFHP77FHrVD2wiD1iV9aSrS1tCMVhfYiXSeG72uHKkhBGw7QELC5gBBhV2h1qmjro6AKiz7K7gK7vgJaRoXN8AxJJ7GjncGos38BkxjHewt2K3YoEUeJAA1o7RBQaYxXkvyfU3FE5fon2qYPmSupzaBGay1ANvDddytmG2PLRvntf9bTmLP8RCCQnAzvsXjQ8WyU8ZnyBGnpvS"}" href="https://cna.st/affiliate-link/gVLYTFHP77FHrVD2wiD1iV9aSrS1tCMVhfYiXSeG72uHKkhBGw7QELC5gBBhV2h1qmjro6AKiz7K7gK7vgJaRoXN8AxJJ7GjncGos38BkxjHewt2K3YoEUeJAA1o7RBQaYxXkvyfU3FE5fon2qYPmSupzaBGay1ANvDddytmG2PLRvntf9bTmLP8RCCQnAzvsXjQ8WyU8ZnyBGnpvS" rel="sponsored" target="_blank" data-aps-asin="B0CMDRCZBJ" data-aps-asc-tag="wirednl-20">Galaxy S24</a> (used or new), or wait for the Galaxy S25 to dip on sale.</p><p>I used the S24 FE for close to a month and had a perfectly fine time with it. It uses Samsung's Exynos processor, and I haven't had any performance issues whatsoever; my benchmark scores put it a smidge below the Galaxy S24 and its Snapdragon chipset. You still get access to all the <a href="https://www.wired.com/story/samsung-galaxy-unpacked-2024/">original Galaxy AI features</a>, nearly the same triple-camera experience, the 7-year software update policy, and perks like IP68 water resistance and wireless charging. What you miss out on are a higher resolution display, extra RAM, and more storage options. The bezels are a smidge thicker around the screen, which doesn't support LTPO (the <a href="https://www.wired.com/story/high-refresh-rate-explained/">tech that allows the display</a> to move from 1 Hz to 120 Hz to conserve battery life). The fingerprint scanner is also optical and not ultrasonic, and while it's been quite responsive for me, ultrasonic scanners are often more reliable. Battery life has been solid; after several weeks of use, I average 30 percent left in the tank by midnight, and that's with a few hours of GPS navigation and music streaming thrown in, not to mention too many hours of riffling through Instagram Reels.</p><table><thead><tr><th>Specs</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td><strong>Display:</strong> 6.7 inch, 120 Hz, AMOLED</td></tr><tr><td><strong>Processor and RAM:</strong> Samsung Exynos 2400e with 8 GB of RAM</td></tr><tr><td><strong>Storage:</strong> 128 GB</td></tr><tr><td><strong>Battery:</strong> 4,700 mAh</td></tr><tr><td><strong>Cameras:</strong> 50-MP main camera, 12-MP ultrawide, 8-MP telephoto (3x), and 10-MP selfie camera</td></tr><tr><td><strong>Updates (from date of manufacture):</strong> 7 years</td></tr><tr><td><strong>Extras:</strong> Wireless charging, IP68, fingerprint unlock, NFC</td></tr><tr><td><strong>Carrier compatibility:</strong> Works on all three major US networks</td></tr></tbody></table></div></div><div class="UnifiedProductCardReviewSection-epzOlN gUIihX"></div></div></div></div></div></li><li class="gallery__slides__slide hide-ad"><div class="AdWrapper-dQtivb fZrssQ gallery-slide ad ad--sponsor-product"><div class="ad__slot ad__slot--sponsor-product" data-node-id="1uai86" data-ad-index="0"></div></div></li><li class="gallery__slides__slide" id="684312e330923e2a12cd9216"><div><div class="UnifiedProductCardBody-hDFFwy jmjUSU product-embed impressionTracking" data-item="{"ctaAnalyticsName":"buy-button-click","bookmarkMeta":{"slug":"gallery/best-samsung-phones","title":"The Best Samsung Phones"},"brand":{"name":"Samsung"},"contentType":"product","ctaHref":null,"dangerousCredit":"","dangerousHed":"Best Budget Samsung Phone","dek":["div",["p","Samsung makes ",["em","solid"]," budget phones, but not the best. BaseText-ewhhUZ UnifiedProductCardDescriptionWrapper-dDTcJP iUEiRd ikAILL dASmJi"><div><p>Samsung makes <em>solid</em> budget phones, but not the best. I highly recommend glossing through my <a href="https://www.wired.com/story/best-cheap-phones/">Best Cheap Phones guide</a> because you might be better served with a <a href="https://www.wired.com/review/google-pixel-9a/">Pixel 9a</a>, <a href="https://www.wired.com/review/nothing-phone-3a-and-phone-3a-pro/">Nothing Phone (3a)</a>, or <a href="https://www.wired.com/review/motorola-moto-g-power-2025/">Moto G Power</a>. But if you want to stick with Samsung, the Galaxy A26 is the best at the moment (<a href="https://www.wired.com/review/samsung-galaxy-a26-and-galaxy-a36/">6/10, WIRED Review</a>). It's not flashy—the glossy black design is dull and attracts a ton of smudges and dust—but it has many of the features you want for not much money.</p><p>Performance is standout here. The Exynos 1380 delivers a mostly smooth experience, with few stutters, and the 120-Hz 6.7-inch screen helps things feel fluid. The screen is bright enough to read on sunny days, though the colors get washed out at the max brightness. This is one of the last few Samsung phones with a microSD card slot, if that matters to you, so you can expand storage on top of the base 128 GB. The battery easily lasts a full day with average use, and the best part is Samsung will deliver 6 years of updates—OS and security patches—which is unparalleled at this price.</p><table><thead><tr><th>Specs</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td><strong>Display:</strong> 6.7-inch 120 Hz, AMOLED</td></tr><tr><td><strong>Processor and RAM:</strong> Samsung Exynos 1380 with 6 GB of RAM</td></tr><tr><td><strong>Storage:</strong> 128 GB with microSD slot</td></tr><tr><td><strong>Battery:</strong> 5,000 mAh</td></tr><tr><td><strong>Cameras:</strong> 50-MP main camera, 8-MP ultrawide, 2-MP macro, and 13-MP selfie camera</td></tr><tr><td><strong>Updates (from date of manufacture):</strong> 6 years</td></tr><tr><td><strong>Extras:</strong> IP67, eSIM, NFC, fingerprint unlock</td></tr><tr><td><strong>Carrier compatibility:</strong> Works on all three major US networks</td></tr></tbody></table></div></div><div class="UnifiedProductCardReviewSection-epzOlN gUIihX"></div></div></div></div></div></li></ul></div></div></div></div></div><div class="LazyChunk-lbwTjc cwDPsI"><div data-testid="RowWrapper" class="BaseWrap-sc-gjQpdd RowWrapper-UmqTg iUEiRd HEhan GalleryPageChunkRow-eNGlGj bhvZSw"><div class="GridWrapper-cAzTTK iBVjDs grid grid-margins grid-items-2 grid-layout--adrail narrow"><div class="GridItem-buujkM stRKV grid--item grid-layout__content"><div class=""><ul class="GalleryPageSlides-hIivta gKmvyw"><li class="gallery__slides__slide" id="6830b23d9ff9f250ab203aa2"><div><div class="UnifiedProductCardBody-hDFFwy jmjUSU product-embed impressionTracking" data-item="{"ctaAnalyticsName":"buy-button-click","bookmarkMeta":{"slug":"gallery/best-samsung-phones","title":"The Best Samsung Phones"},"brand":{"name":"Samsung"},"contentType":"product","ctaHref":null,"dangerousCredit":"","dangerousHed":"An Ultra-Thin Samsung Phone","dek":["div",["p","Have you ever wanted a ",["em","really"]," thin and lightweight phone? No? Well, Samsung has an option for you anyway. The late-entry Galaxy S25 Edge sits in the middle of Samsung's flagship lineup and matches several features of the Galaxy S25 Ultra, like a titanium frame, stronger front glass, and 4K 120 fps video recording. All the cameras even have autofocus. But it made several sacrifices to achieve its amazingly slim 5.8-mm frame (for context, the S25 Ultra is 8.2 mm thick). There's no stylus, no telephoto camera, and worst of all, the battery capacity has been slashed."],["p","We've seen this before—thin phones have always compromised on battery life, and that's no different here. I constantly had to baby this phone's 3,900-mAh battery with average to heavy usage, and that's just not acceptable for a $1,100 smartphone today. If you find yourself constantly near a power source and you think you'll enjoy the slim and light design, then go for it. It's still an excellent flagship in many other ways. But battery life is routinely a top concern for most people, and it'll disappoint here."],["table",["thead",["tr",["th",["strong","Specs"]],["th",["strong","Samsung Galaxy S25
