gwSJOK"><div class="BaseWrap-sc-gjQpdd BaseText-ewhhUZ UnifiedProductCardDescriptionWrapper-dDTcJP iUEiRd ikAILL dASmJi"><div><p>Have you ever wanted a <em>really</em> thin and lightweight phone? No? Well, Samsung has an option for you anyway. The late-entry Galaxy S25 Edge sits in the middle of Samsung's flagship lineup and matches several features of the Galaxy S25 Ultra, like a titanium frame, stronger front glass, and 4K 120 fps video recording. All the cameras even have autofocus. But it made several sacrifices to achieve its amazingly slim 5.8-mm frame (for context, the S25 Ultra is 8.2 mm thick). There's no stylus, no telephoto camera, and worst of all, the battery capacity has been slashed.</p><p>We've seen this before—thin phones have always compromised on battery life, and that's no different here. I constantly had to baby this phone's 3,900-mAh battery with average to heavy usage, and that's just not acceptable for a $1,100 smartphone today. If you find yourself constantly near a power source and you think you'll enjoy the slim and light design, then go for it. It's still an excellent flagship in many other ways. But battery life is routinely a top concern for most people, and it'll disappoint here.</p><table><thead><tr><th><strong>Specs</strong></th><th><strong>Samsung Galaxy S25 Edge</strong></th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td><strong>Display:</strong></td><td>6.7 inch, 120 Hz, AMOLED</td></tr><tr><td><strong>Processor and RAM:</strong></td><td>Qualcomm Snapdragon 8 Elite with 12 GB RAM</td></tr><tr><td><strong>Storage:</strong></td><td>256- and 512-GB options</td></tr><tr><td><strong>Battery:</strong></td><td>3,900 mAh</td></tr><tr><td><strong>Cameras:</strong></td><td>200-MP main, 12-MP ultrawide, 12-MP selfie camera</td></tr><tr><td><strong>Updates:</strong></td><td>7 years</td></tr><tr><td><strong>Extras:</strong></td><td>Qi2 Ready 15-watt wireless charging, 25-watt fast charging, IP68, titanium frame, NFC, fingerprint unlock</td></tr><tr><td><strong>Carrier compatibility:</strong></td><td>Works on all three major US networks</td></tr></tbody></table></div></div><div class="UnifiedProductCardReviewSection-epzOlN gUIihX"></div></div></div></div></div></li><li class="gallery__slides__slide" id="67173d1b4579622521b74822"><div><div class="UnifiedProductCardBody-hDFFwy jmjUSU product-embed impressionTracking" data-item="{"ctaAnalyticsName":"buy-button-click","bookmarkMeta":{"slug":"gallery/best-samsung-phones","title":"The Best Samsung Phones"},"brand":{"name":"Samsung"},"contentType":"product","ctaHref":null,"dangerousCredit":"","dangerousHed":"A Great Flip Phone","dek":["div",["p",["em",["strong","Note:"]," Samsung is expected to unveil the Galaxy Z Flip7 in July at its next Galaxy Unpacked event. I recommend holding off on the Z Flip6."]],["p","Want something with a little more personality? Samsung has been making folding smartphones longer than any other company, and the Galaxy Z Flip6 is the most refined version to date (",["a",{"href":"https://www.wired.com/review/samsung-galaxy-z-fold6-and-galaxy-z-flip6/","isExternal":false},"7/10, WIRED Review"],"). It's not my ",["em","favorite"]," flip-style folding phone—that'd be the ",["a",{"href":"https://www.wired.com/review/motorola-razr-ultra-and-razr-2025/","isExternal":false},"Motorola Razr Ultra"]," and its larger external screen—but the Flip6 is a close second, and it one-ups Motorola's device on a few fronts. The hinge design is more responsive and feels more durable, plus there's longer software support and better cameras."],["p","The main reason to buy a flippy folding phone? You get a normal-sized smartphone with the ability to fold it in half, perfect for smaller pockets, and it's just easier to carry. The main drawback? Battery life isn't great. Even with average use, there's a good chance you may need a top-up before the day's end. Make sure to bring a ",["a",{"href":"https://www.wired.com/gallery/best-portable-chargers-power-banks/","isExternal":false},"battery pack"],"! Also, while Samsung added a vapor chamber system for better cooling in this model, my unit still gave me a notification that the device needed to cool down after using GPS navigation on a hot day in Paris."],["p","But a folding phone's best trick is with its cameras: You can take selfies with the Flip6's superior rear cameras by folding the device into a 90-degree angle and using the external display as a camera viewfinder to ensure you're in the shot. Read my ",["a",{"href":"https://www.wired.com/gallery/best-folding-phones/","isExternal":false},"Best Folding Phones"]," guide for more flipping dASmJi"><div><p><em><strong>Note:</strong> Samsung is expected to unveil the Galaxy Z Flip7 in July at its next Galaxy Unpacked event. I recommend holding off on the Z Flip6.</em></p><p>Want something with a little more personality? Samsung has been making folding smartphones longer than any other company, and the Galaxy Z Flip6 is the most refined version to date (<a href="https://www.wired.com/review/samsung-galaxy-z-fold6-and-galaxy-z-flip6/">7/10, WIRED Review</a>). It's not my <em>favorite</em> flip-style folding phone—that'd be the <a href="https://www.wired.com/review/motorola-razr-ultra-and-razr-2025/">Motorola Razr Ultra</a> and its larger external screen—but the Flip6 is a close second, and it one-ups Motorola's device on a few fronts. The hinge design is more responsive and feels more durable, plus there's longer software support and better cameras.</p><p>The main reason to buy a flippy folding phone? You get a normal-sized smartphone with the ability to fold it in half, perfect for smaller pockets, and it's just easier to carry. The main drawback? Battery life isn't great. Even with average use, there's a good chance you may need a top-up before the day's end. Make sure to bring a <a href="https://www.wired.com/gallery/best-portable-chargers-power-banks/">battery pack</a>! Also, while Samsung added a vapor chamber system for better cooling in this model, my unit still gave me a notification that the device needed to cool down after using GPS navigation on a hot day in Paris.</p><p>But a folding phone's best trick is with its cameras: You can take selfies with the Flip6's superior rear cameras by folding the device into a 90-degree angle and using the external display as a camera viewfinder to ensure you're in the shot. Read my <a href="https://www.wired.com/gallery/best-folding-phones/">Best Folding Phones</a> guide for more flipping fun.</p><table><thead><tr><th>Specs</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td><strong>External display:</strong> 3.4 inches, 60 Hz, AMOLED</td></tr><tr><td><strong>Internal display:</strong> 6.7-inch, 120-Hz LTPO, AMOLED</td></tr><tr><td><strong>Processor and RAM:</strong> Snapdragon 8 Gen 3 with 12 GB RAM</td></tr><tr><td><strong>Storage:</strong> 256- or 512-GB options</td></tr><tr><td><strong>Battery:</strong> 4,000 mAh</td></tr><tr><td><strong>Cameras:</strong> 50-MP main camera, 12-MP ultrawide, 10-MP selfie camera</td></tr><tr><td><strong>Updates (from date of manufacture):</strong> 7 years</td></tr><tr><td><strong>Extras:</strong> IPX8, fingerprint sensor, NFC, wireless charging</td></tr><tr><td><strong>Carrier compatibility:</strong> Works on all three major US networks</td></tr></tbody></table></div></div><div class="UnifiedProductCardReviewSection-epzOlN gUIihX"></div></div></div></div></div></li></ul></div></div></div></div></div><div This iteration has a close to “normal” smartphone experience on the exterior 6.3-inch screen. It's still a bit narrow, but it's more usable than its predecessors. Open the phone up and there's a vast 7.6-inch AMOLED screen staring at your face, turning this folding phone into a tiny tablet. You can use your apps in this full-sized view (it's especially great when these apps are tablet-optimized), or you can use split-screen and get two normal-looking app windows next to each other. A persistent taskbar follows you throughout the interface like the dock on MacOS or Windows, letting you hop into another app at a moment's notice. dASmJi"><div><p><em><strong>Note:</strong> Samsung is expected to unveil the Galaxy Z Fold7 in July at its Galaxy Unpacked event. I recommend holding off on the Z Fold7.</em> </p><p>If money is no object and you <em>love</em> <a href="https://www.wired.com/story/how-to-set-up-multiple-monitors/">two screens</a> on your desktop, you'll probably like the Galaxy Z Fold6 (<a href="https://www.wired.com/review/samsung-galaxy-z-fold6-and-galaxy-z-flip6/">7/10, WIRED Review</a>). This iteration has a close to “normal” smartphone experience on the exterior 6.3-inch screen. It's still a bit narrow, but it's more usable than its predecessors. Open the phone up and there's a vast 7.6-inch AMOLED screen staring at your face, turning this folding phone into a tiny tablet. You can use your apps in this full-sized view (it's especially great when these apps are tablet-optimized), or you can use split-screen and get two normal-looking app windows next to each other. A persistent taskbar follows you throughout the interface like the dock on MacOS or Windows, letting you hop into another app at a moment's notice. It's great for getting stuff <em>done</em>.</p><p>Unfortunately, the 2024 model got a price bump despite minor changes, and the competition also feels like it has blown past what Samsung has been doing for years—the <a href="https://www.wired.com/review/google-pixel-9-pro-fold/">Pixel 9 Pro Fold</a> has an even more normal exterior screen, and the <a href="https://www.wired.com/review/oneplus-open/">OnePlus Open</a> has richer multitasking capabilities. Honor's folding phone is <a href="https://www.wired.com/review/honor-magic-v3/">also the world's thinnest</a>. Rumors suggest the Galaxy Z Fold7 will be a bigger upgrade with new features and capabilities, so you should wait to see what's new. On the other hand, Samsung is set up to have the best repair network if something goes wrong, and the build quality of the Fold6 is excellent.</p><table><thead><tr><th>Specs</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td><strong>External display:</strong> 6.3-inch, 120-Hz LTPO, AMOLED</td></tr><tr><td><strong>Internal display:</strong> 7.6-inch, 120-Hz LTPO, AMOLED</td></tr><tr><td><strong>Processor and RAM:</strong> Snapdragon 8 Gen 3 with 12 GB RAM</td></tr><tr><td><strong>Storage:</strong> 256, 512 GB, or 1 TB options</td></tr><tr><td><strong>Battery:</strong> 4,400 mAh</td></tr><tr><td><strong>Cameras:</strong> 50-MP main camera, 10-MP telephoto (3X), 12-MP ultrawide, 10-MP front camera, 4-MP inner selfie camera</td></tr><tr><td><strong>Updates (from date of manufacture):</strong> 7 years</td></tr><tr><td><strong>Extras:</strong> IPX8, fingerprint sensor, NFC, wireless charging</td></tr><tr><td><strong>Carrier compatibility:</strong> Works on all three major US networks</td></tr></tbody></table></div></div><div class="UnifiedProductCardReviewSection-epzOlN gUIihX"></div></div></div></div></div></li><li class="gallery__slides__slide" id="65b9593057a75cccd4844fc1"><div><div class="UnifiedProductCardBody-hDFFwy jmjUSU product-embed impressionTracking" data-item="{"ctaAnalyticsName":"buy-button-click","bookmarkMeta":{"slug":"gallery/best-samsung-phones","title":"The Best Samsung Phones"},"brand":{"name":"Samsung"},"contentType":"product","ctaHref":null,"dangerousCredit":"","dangerousHed":"Last Year&#39;s Flagships","dek":["div",["p","There's nothing wrong with buying last year's flagship phone. You often can score a good deal, especially on the used marketplace, and frankly, the Galaxy S24 series (",["a",{"href":"https://www.wired.com/review/samsung-galaxy-s24-s24-plus-and-s24-ultra/","isExternal":false},"8/10, WIRED Recommends"],") is shockingly identical to the latest Galaxy S25 devices. There's the 6.2-inch Galaxy S24, 6.7-inch Galaxy S24+, and 6.8-inch Galaxy S24 Ultra. They're powerful through and through, though they get a little warm and may not deliver as smooth gameplay in intensive games as much as the newer Galaxy S25 series. (Performance is otherwise pretty flawless.) I break down each of these devices ",["a",{"href":"https://www.wired.com/story/which-samsung-galaxy-s24-model-to-buy/","isExternal":false},"even further here if"]," you're stumped on which one to get. UnifiedProductCardDescriptionWrapper-dDTcJP iUEiRd ikAILL dASmJi"><div><p>There's nothing wrong with buying last year's flagship phone. You often can score a good deal, especially on the used marketplace, and frankly, the Galaxy S24 series (<a href="https://www.wired.com/review/samsung-galaxy-s24-s24-plus-and-s24-ultra/">8/10, WIRED Recommends</a>) is shockingly identical to the latest Galaxy S25 devices. There's the 6.2-inch Galaxy S24, 6.7-inch Galaxy S24+, and 6.8-inch Galaxy S24 Ultra. They're powerful through and through, though they get a little warm and may not deliver as smooth gameplay in intensive games as much as the newer Galaxy S25 series. (Performance is otherwise pretty flawless.) I break down each of these devices <a href="https://www.wired.com/story/which-samsung-galaxy-s24-model-to-buy/">even further here if</a> you're stumped on which one to get. Just don't pay MSRP—you may as well buy the latest and greatest if that's the case.</p><table><thead><tr><th>Galaxy S24</th><th>Galaxy S24+</th><th>Galaxy S24 Ultra</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td><strong>Display:</strong> 6.2 inch, 120-Hz LTPO, AMOLED</td><td>6.7 inch, 120-Hz LTPO, AMOLED</td><td>6.8 inch, 120-Hz LTPO, AMOLED</td></tr><tr><td><strong>Processor and RAM:</strong> Qualcomm Snapdragon 8 Gen 3 with 8 GB RAM</td><td>Qualcomm Snapdragon 8 Gen 3 with 12 GB RAM</td><td>Qualcomm Snapdragon 8 Gen 3 with 12 GB RAM</td></tr><tr><td><strong>Storage:</strong> 128 and 256 GB</td><td>256 and 512 GB</td><td>256, 512 GB, 1 TB</td></tr><tr><td><strong>Battery:</strong> 4,000 mAh</td><td>4,900 mAh</td><td>5,000 mAh</td></tr><tr><td><strong>Cameras:</strong> 50-MP main camera, 12-MP ultrawide, 10-MP telephoto, and 12-MP selfie camera</td><td>50-MP main camera, 12-MP ultrawide, 10-MP telephoto, and 12-MP selfie camera</td><td>200-MP main camera, 12-MP ultrawide, 10-MP telephoto (3X), 50-MP telephoto (5X), and 12-MP selfie camera</td></tr><tr><td><strong>Updates (from date of manufacture):</strong> 7 years</td><td>7 years</td><td>7 years</td></tr><tr><td><strong>Extras:</strong> Wireless charging, IP68, fingerprint unlock, NFC</td><td>Wireless charging, IP68, fingerprint unlock, NFC</td><td>Wireless charging, IP68, fingerprint unlock, NFC, titanium frame, S Pen stylus</td></tr><tr><td><strong>Carrier compatibility:</strong> Works on all three major US networks</td><td>Works Sure, Samsung is promising six years of software updates, but that remarkable update window doesn't matter when the phone is frustratingly slow, and you want to throw it out the window. If you barely plan on using this device but want something from a reliable brand that will stay secure, the Galaxy A16 is fine. Its performance just isn't competitive with other similarly priced phones.</p><p>If you're looking to save some cash, it's fine to buy Samsung's <a href="https://www.wired.com/review/samsung-galaxy-s23-and-s23-ultra/">Galaxy S23 range</a> or the <a href="https://www.wired.com/story/samsung-galaxy-s23-fe-tab-s9-fe-buds-fe/">Galaxy S23 FE</a> from 2023, as long as the prices are a good deal lower than the original MSRP. (They're hard to find at most major retailers.) These phones will still get support for a while, and they're pretty great. I don't think it's worth buying anything older.</p><h2>Should You Invest in Samsung's Ecosystem?</h2><figure class="AssetEmbedWrapper-eVDQiB byBkf asset-embed"><div class="AssetEmbedAssetContainer-eJxoAx dBHGoQ asset-embed__asset-container"><span class="SpanWrapper-umhxW lgCwTv responsive-asset AssetEmbedResponsiveAsset-cXBNxi lqMXz asset-embed__responsive-asset"><picture class="ResponsiveImagePicture-cWuUZO dUOtEa AssetEmbedResponsiveAsset-cXBNxi lqMXz asset-embed__responsive-asset responsive-image"><noscript><img alt="Samsung Galaxy Devices" class="ResponsiveImageContainer-eybHBd fptoWY responsive-image__image" src="https://media.wired.com/photos/668da4a4f1cf59d7e4ba43af/master/w_1600%2Cc_limit/Galaxy-Devices.jpg" srcSet="https://media.wired.com/photos/668da4a4f1cf59d7e4ba43af/master/w_120,c_limit/Galaxy-Devices.jpg 120w, https://media.wired.com/photos/668da4a4f1cf59d7e4ba43af/master/w_240,c_limit/Galaxy-Devices.jpg 240w, https://media.wired.com/photos/668da4a4f1cf59d7e4ba43af/master/w_320,c_limit/Galaxy-Devices.jpg 320w, https://media.wired.com/photos/668da4a4f1cf59d7e4ba43af/master/w_640,c_limit/Galaxy-Devices.jpg 640w, https://media.wired.com/photos/668da4a4f1cf59d7e4ba43af/master/w_960,c_limit/Galaxy-Devices.jpg 960w, https://media.wired.com/photos/668da4a4f1cf59d7e4ba43af/master/w_1280,c_limit/Galaxy-Devices.jpg 1280w, https://media.wired.com/photos/668da4a4f1cf59d7e4ba43af/master/w_1600,c_limit/Galaxy-Devices.jpg 1600w" sizes="100vw"/></noscript></picture></span></div><div class="CaptionWrapper-jSZdqE fJvQtP caption AssetEmbedCaption-fNQBPI dDrfgT asset-embed__caption" data-testid="caption-wrapper"><span class="BaseWrap-sc-gjQpdd BaseText-ewhhUZ CaptionCredit-ejegDm iUEiRd isTgyB fNaHcW caption__credit">Photograph: Julian Chokkattu</span></div></figure><p>Samsung is one of the few smartphone manufacturers that can match Apple in its hardware ecosystem. class="BaseWrap-sc-gjQpdd BaseText-ewhhUZ CaptionCredit-ejegDm iUEiRd isTgyB fNaHcW caption__credit">Photograph: Julian Chokkattu</span></div></figure><p>With the Galaxy S24 series, Samsung launched “<a href="https://www.wired.com/story/samsung-galaxy-unpacked-2024/">Galaxy AI</a>," a selection of artificial intelligence features, many of which are powered by <a href="https://www.wired.com/story/google-gemini-generative-ai-boom/">Google's Gemini large language models</a>. These enable smart features that may be helpful day to day, like real-time translations during phone calls, real-time transcriptions in Samsung's Voice Recorder app, the ability to summarize long paragraphs of text in the Samsung Notes app, or change a sentence's tone with the Samsung Keyboard. In the Galaxy S25 series, Galaxy AI expanded to include Gemini as the default voice assistant and the ability for Gemini to work with multiple apps simultaneously. It also debuted Drawing Assist, which lets you sketch or enter a prompt and get an AI-generated image.</p><native-ad position="sponsor-product" shouldDisplayLabel="true"></native-ad><p>You can find many of these features by heading to <strong>Settings > Galaxy AI</strong> to toggle them on or off.</p><h2>What Is Samsung DeX?</h2><figure class="AssetEmbedWrapper-eVDQiB byBkf asset-embed"><div caption__credit">Courtesy of David Nield</span></div></figure><p>Samsung's DeX (short for “desktop experience”) launched in 2017, and it's a way to plug in your Samsung phone to an external monitor and trigger a desktop version of the Android OS, all completely powered by the phone. You can find a list of <a data-offer-url="https://www.samsung.com/us/support/answer/ANS10001955/" class="external-link" data-event-click="{"element":"ExternalLink","outgoingURL":"https://www.samsung.com/us/support/answer/ANS10001955/"}" href="https://www.samsung.com/us/support/answer/ANS10001955/" rel="nofollow" target="_blank">compatible Samsung phones here</a>, and you'll need a <a href="https://www.wired.com/gallery/best-computer-monitors/">monitor</a>, <a href="https://www.wired.com/gallery/best-gaming-mouse/">mouse</a>, and <a href="https://www.wired.com/gallery/best-keyboards/">keyboard</a>, plus a <a href="https://www.wired.com/gallery/best-usb-c-cables/">cable</a> to connect the phone to the monitor. (You can also cast DeX to select screens wirelessly.)</p><ad position="mid-content"></ad><p>When in DeX mode, you can resize Android apps and have them all open in separate windows. It's a proper computing platform, though you probably won't want to use this as a permanent laptop replacement or anything of the sort. It's great if you're visiting another office, or working out of a coffee shop or airplane (if you have a portable display). We have a whole guide <a href="https://www.wired.com/story/how-to-use-samsung-dex-mobile-desktop/">to setting up and using DeX here</a>.</p><h2>How I Test Phones</h2><p>I've been reviewing smartphones for a decade, but one of my earliest smart devices was a <a href="https://www.wired.com/2010/06/samsung-android-phone-heads-to-att/">Samsung Galaxy Captivate</a>, which I got for “free” from my carrier at the time. After working during college, I finally saved enough cash for a <a href="https://www.wired.com/2012/06/samsung-galaxy-s-iii/">Galaxy S3</a>, my first flagship. I've spent years using Samsung phones in my personal life and began reviewing them for work not too long after.</p><p>With each Samsung smartphone, I always put my personal SIM card inside and spend as long as I can (a few weeks) using the phone as my own. I do camera testing and compare the results with similarly priced devices, I benchmark performance and play graphically demanding games to see how they fare, I try out all the new features, and even take calls to make sure that ol' function still works fine.</p><hr/><p><strong><a href="https://www.wired.com/v2/offers/wir_generic_ctrl?source=Site_0_HCL_WIR_EDIT_HARDCODED_0_COMMERCE_AFFILIATE_ZZ"><em>Power up with unlimited access to</em> WIRED</a><em>.</em></strong> <em>Get best-in-class reporting that's too important to ignore for just <del>$2.50</del> $1 per month for 1 year. Not much has changed from its predecessors (seriously, many of the specs are identical), but that doesn't stop them from being excellent and reliable smartphones. The Galaxy S25 is the smallest of the lot with a 6.2-inch screen, and then there's the Galaxy S25+ at 6.7 inches—choosing between them largely depends on whether you want a small, pocketable phone or a big display. There are minuscule differences in some specs, such as how the S25+ comes with 256 GB of storage, and the bigger size means a beefier battery, but they're more alike than ever before.\nYou get every high-end feature you can think of, from UFS 4.0 storage speeds to brilliantly bright AMOLED displays with high 120-Hz refresh rates that ratchet down to 1 Hz to be more energy efficient. The batteries typically last a full day of average use with around 30 to 40 percent left, and there's an excellent triple-camera system with 3x optical zoom, an ultrawide in addition to the main camera, and a strong selfie shooter. These phones also put out some of the best video footage out of the box, so they're great for budding TikTokkers. Arguably, the most notable improvement over prior models is performance—the efficient Snapdragon 8 Elite chipset paired with Samsung's improved cooling technology means it can handle demanding games like Genshin Impact with fewer stutters and without getting warm too quickly. I'm not fond of the design—they're a bit bland—but at least you can snag them in some unique colors exclusive to Samsung.com.\nSamsung focused on several Galaxy AI features in this release, like making Google's Gemini the default voice assistant when you press and hold the power button. Gemini can now integrate with multiple apps—native Samsung and Google apps—so you can ask it to find the games for your favorite basketball team and add them to your calendar. Some of these AI features, outlined here, are helpful, while others, like Now Brief, are not.\n\n\n\nSpecs: Galaxy S25\nGalaxy S25+\n\n\n\n\nDisplay: 6.2 inches, 120-Hz LTPO, AMOLED\n6.7 inches, 120-Hz LTPO, AMOLED\n\n\nProcessor and RAM: Qualcomm Snapdragon 8 Elite with 12 GB of RAM\nQualcomm Snapdragon 8 Elite with 12 GB of RAM\n\n\nStorage: 128, 256, and 512 GB\n256 and 512 GB\n\n\nBattery: 4,000 mAh\n4,900 mAh\n\n\nCameras: 50-MP main camera, 12-MP ultrawide, 10-MP telephoto (3x), and 12-MP selfie camera\n50-MP main camera, 12-MP ultrawide, 10-MP telephoto (3x), and 12-MP selfie camera\n\n\nUpdates (from date of manufacture): 7 years\n7 years\n\n\nExtras: Non-magnetic Qi 2.1 wireless charging (Qi2 Ready with case). That'd be the Galaxy S25 Ultra (7\u002F10, WIRED Recommends), though it doesn't feel as “ultra” as its predecessors. This phone shares many specs and features with the standard Galaxy S25 series—even the design is unified—but it has more durable front glass for better drop protection and scratch resistance, as well as a titanium frame. However, this doesn't mean it's less prone to breakage (use a case!). It's the biggest phone of the trio, meaning it has the largest battery, which can extend into the morning of a second day. Notably, the S25 Ultra has a built-in stylus—you pull it out from the bottom and start writing on the screen to jot down notes or doodle when bored on a Zoom call. Unfortunately, Samsung removed the ability to use it as a Bluetooth remote for the camera.\nSpeaking of, the cameras are where it goes the extra mile—not only is the main camera a 200-megapixel shooter that can preserve more details, but there are also two telephoto cameras in addition to the new and improved 50-megapixel ultrawide. At 3x and 5x, you have better zoom options with great quality, though this starts to diminish in low light. (I do miss the 10x optical zoom from the Galaxy S23.) The ultrawide also performs well in low light and has delivered sharper results than the Google Pixel 9 Pro and iPhone 16 Pro Max.\nBut just because this is Samsung's top-of-the-line phone, it doesn't mean this is the right phone for you. If you don't care about a stylus and don't use the zoom functions on a smartphone camera much, there are few reasons to spend so much on the S25 Ultra.\n\n\n\nSpecs\n\n\n\n\nDisplay: 6.9 inches, 120-Hz LTPO, AMOLED\n\n\nProcessor and RAM: Snapdragon 8 Elite with 12 GB RAM\n\n\nStorage: 256-GB, 512-GB, and 1-TB options\n\n\nBattery: 5,000 mAh\n\n\nCameras: 200-MP main, 50-MP ultrawide, 10-MP telephoto (3X), 50-MP telephoto (5X), and 12-MP selfie camera\n\n\nUpdates (from date of manufacture): 7 years\n\n\nExtras: Non-magnetic Qi 2.1 wireless charging (Qi2 Ready with case). In any case, the S24 FE is only worth buying if you can catch it on sale for around $500 or below—anything more, and you may as well buy a Galaxy S24 (used or new), or wait for the Galaxy S25 to dip on sale.\nI used the S24 FE for close to a month and had a perfectly fine time with it. It uses Samsung's Exynos processor, and I haven't had any performance issues whatsoever; my benchmark scores put it a smidge below the Galaxy S24 and its Snapdragon chipset. You still get access to all the original Galaxy AI features, nearly the same triple-camera experience, the 7-year software update policy, and perks like IP68 water resistance and wireless charging. What you miss out on are a higher resolution display, extra RAM, and more storage options. The bezels are a smidge thicker around the screen, which doesn't support LTPO (the tech that allows the display to move from 1 Hz to 120 Hz to conserve battery life). The fingerprint scanner is also optical and not ultrasonic, and while it's been quite responsive for me, ultrasonic scanners are often more reliable. Battery life has been solid; after several weeks of use, I average 30 percent left in the tank by midnight, and that's with a few hours of GPS navigation and music streaming thrown in, not to mention too many hours of riffling through Instagram Reels.\n\n\n\nSpecs\n\n\n\n\nDisplay: 6.7 inch, 120 Hz, AMOLED\n\n\nProcessor and RAM: Samsung Exynos 2400e with 8 GB of RAM\n\n\nStorage: 128 GB\n\n\nBattery: 4,700 mAh\n\n\nCameras: 50-MP main camera, 12-MP ultrawide, 8-MP telephoto (3x), and 10-MP selfie camera\n\n\nUpdates (from date of manufacture): 7 years\n\n\nExtras: Wireless charging, IP68, fingerprint unlock, NFC\n\n\nCarrier compatibility: Works on all three major US networks","offers":[{"@type":"Offer","name":"Galaxy S24 FE","price":"525","priceCurrency":"USD","url":"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.amazon.com\u002Fdp\u002FB0DCLD9PLY","offeredBy":{"@type":"Organization","name":"Amazon"}},{"@type":"Offer","name":"Galaxy S24 FE","price":"525","priceCurrency":"USD","url":"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.samsung.com\u002Fus\u002Fsmartphones\u002Fgalaxy-s24-fe\u002Fbuy\u002Fgalaxy-s24-fe-128gb-unlocked-sm-s721uzkaxaa\u002F","offeredBy":{"@type":"Organization","name":"Samsung"}},{"@type":"Offer","name":"Galaxy S24 FE","price":"525","priceCurrency":"USD","url":"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.bestbuy.com\u002Fsite\u002Fsamsung-galaxy-s24-fe-128gb-unlocked-graphite\u002F6599405.p?skuId=6599405","offeredBy":{"@type":"Organization","name":"Best Buy"}}]}},{"@context":"https:\u002F\u002Fschema.org","@type":"ListItem","position":4,"item":{"@type":"Product","name":"Galaxy A26","brand":{"@type":"Brand","name":"Samsung"},"url":"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.wired.com\u002Fgallery\u002Fbest-samsung-phones\u002F#684312e330923e2a12cd9216","image":["https:\u002F\u002Fmedia.wired.com\u002Fphotos\u002F684367923c448a9bc4a5dc8e\u002F4:3\u002Fw_960,c_limit\u002FGalaxy%20A26%20SOURCE%20Julian%20Chokkattu.png"],"description":"Samsung makes solid budget phones, but not the best. I highly recommend glossing through my Best Cheap Phones guide because you might be better served with a Pixel 9a, Nothing Phone (3a), or Moto G Power. But if you want to stick with Samsung, the Galaxy A26 is the best at the moment (6\u002F10, WIRED Review). It's not flashy—the glossy black design is dull and attracts a ton of smudges and dust—but it has many of the features you want for not much money.\nPerformance is standout here. The Exynos 1380 delivers a mostly smooth experience, with few stutters, and the 120-Hz 6.7-inch screen helps things feel fluid. The screen is bright enough to read on sunny days, though the colors get washed out at the max brightness. This is one of the last few Samsung phones with a microSD card slot, if that matters to you, so you can expand storage on top of the base 128 GB. The battery easily lasts a full day with average use, and the best part is Samsung will deliver 6 years of updates—OS and security patches—which is unparalleled at this price.\n\n\n\nSpecs\n\n\n\n\nDisplay: 6.7-inch 120 Hz, AMOLED\n\n\nProcessor and RAM: Samsung Exynos 1380 with 6 GB of RAM\n\n\nStorage: 128 GB with microSD slot\n\n\nBattery: 5,000 mAh\n\n\nCameras: 50-MP main camera, 8-MP ultrawide, 2-MP macro, and 13-MP selfie camera\n\n\nUpdates (from date of manufacture): 6 years\n\n\nExtras: IP67, eSIM, NFC, fingerprint unlock\n\n\nCarrier compatibility: Works on all three major US networks","offers":[{"@type":"Offer","name":"Galaxy A26","price":"300","priceCurrency":"USD","url":"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.samsung.com\u002Fus\u002Fsmartphones\u002Fgalaxy-a26\u002Fbuy\u002Fgalaxy-a26-5g-128gb-unlocked-sm-a266uzkaxaa\u002F","offeredBy":{"@type":"Organization","name":"Samsung"}}]}},{"@context":"https:\u002F\u002Fschema.org","@type":"ListItem","position":5,"item":{"@type":"Product","name":"Galaxy S25 Edge","brand":{"@type":"Brand","name":"Samsung"},"url":"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.wired.com\u002Fgallery\u002Fbest-samsung-phones\u002F#6830b23d9ff9f250ab203aa2","image":["https:\u002F\u002Fmedia.wired.com\u002Fphotos\u002F6831137f6efa792c1c1cc0f9\u002F4:3\u002Fw_960,c_limit\u002FSamsung%20Galaxy%20S25%20Edge_%20Photograph%20Julian%20Chokkattu.png"],"description":"Have you ever wanted a really thin and lightweight phone? No? Well, Samsung has an option for you anyway. The late-entry Galaxy S25 Edge sits in the middle of Samsung's flagship lineup and matches several features of the Galaxy S25 Ultra, like a titanium frame, stronger front glass, and 4K 120 fps video recording. All the cameras even have autofocus. But it made several sacrifices to achieve its amazingly slim 5.8-mm frame (for context, the S25 Ultra is 8.2 mm thick). There's no stylus, no telephoto camera, and worst of all, the battery capacity has been slashed.\nWe've seen this before—thin phones have always compromised on battery life, and that's no different here. I constantly had to baby this phone's 3,900-mAh battery with average to heavy usage, and that's just not acceptable for a $1,100 smartphone today. If you find yourself constantly near a power source and you think you'll enjoy the slim and light design, then go for it. It's still an excellent flagship in many other ways. But battery life is routinely a top concern for most people, and it'll disappoint here.\n\n\n\nSpecs\nSamsung Galaxy S25 Edge\n\n\n\n\nDisplay:\n6.7 inch, 120 Hz, AMOLED\n\n\nProcessor and Samsung is expected to unveil the Galaxy Z Flip7 in July at its next Galaxy Unpacked event. I recommend holding off on the Z Flip6.\nWant something with a little more personality? Samsung has been making folding smartphones longer than any other company, and the Galaxy Z Flip6 is the most refined version to date (7\u002F10, WIRED Review). It's not my favorite flip-style folding phone—that'd be the Motorola Razr Ultra and its larger external screen—but the Flip6 is a close second, and it one-ups Motorola's device on a few fronts. The hinge design is more responsive and feels more durable, plus there's longer software support and better cameras.\nThe main reason to buy a flippy folding phone? You get a normal-sized smartphone with the ability to fold it in half, perfect for smaller pockets, and it's just easier to carry. The main drawback? Battery life isn't great. Even with average use, there's a good chance you may need a top-up before the day's end. Make sure to bring a battery pack! Also, while Samsung added a vapor chamber system for better cooling in this model, my unit still gave me a notification that the device needed to cool down after using GPS navigation on a hot day in Paris.\nBut a folding phone's best trick is with its cameras: You can take selfies with the Flip6's superior rear cameras by folding the device into a 90-degree angle and using the external display as a camera viewfinder to ensure you're in the shot. Read my Best Folding Phones guide for more flipping fun.\n\n\n\nSpecs\n\n\n\n\nExternal display: 3.4 inches, 60 Hz, AMOLED\n\n\nInternal display: 6.7-inch, 120-Hz LTPO, AMOLED\n\n\nProcessor and RAM: Snapdragon 8 Gen 3 with 12 GB RAM\n\n\nStorage: 256- or 512-GB options\n\n\nBattery: 4,000 mAh\n\n\nCameras: 50-MP main camera, 12-MP ultrawide, 10-MP selfie camera\n\n\nUpdates (from date of manufacture): 7 years\n\n\nExtras: IPX8, fingerprint sensor, NFC, wireless charging\n\n\nCarrier compatibility: Works on all three major US networks","offers":[{"@type":"Offer","name":"Galaxy Z Flip6","price":"900","priceCurrency":"USD","url":"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.amazon.com\u002FSAMSUNG-Smartphone-Camcorder-Interpreter-Manufacturer\u002Fdp\u002FB0D192WWZ9","offeredBy":{"@type":"Organization","name":"Amazon"}},{"@type":"Offer","name":"Galaxy Z Flip6","price":"1100","priceCurrency":"USD","url":"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.samsung.com\u002Fus\u002Fsmartphones\u002Fgalaxy-z-flip6\u002Fbuy\u002Fgalaxy-z-flip6-256gb-unlocked-sm-f741ulbaxaa\u002F","offeredBy":{"@type":"Organization","name":"Samsung"}},{"@type":"Offer","name":"Galaxy Z Flip6","price":"950","priceCurrency":"USD","url":"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.bestbuy.com\u002Fsite\u002Fsamsung-galaxy-z-flip6-256gb-unlocked-silver-shadow\u002F6586735.p?skuId=6586735","offeredBy":{"@type":"Organization","name":"Best Buy"}}]}},{"@context":"https:\u002F\u002Fschema.org","@type":"ListItem","position":7,"item":{"@type":"Product","name":"Galaxy Z Fold6","brand":{"@type":"Brand","name":"Samsung"},"url":"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.wired.com\u002Fgallery\u002Fbest-samsung-phones\u002F#67173d1d67f4b662eedb19bd","image":["https:\u002F\u002Fmedia.wired.com\u002Fphotos\u002F668da4a9ec66f49a22616809\u002F4:3\u002Fw_960,c_limit\u002FGalaxy%20Z%20Fold6.jpg"],"description":"Note: Samsung is expected to unveil the Galaxy Z Fold7 in July at its Galaxy Unpacked event. I recommend holding off on the Z Fold7.\nIf money is no object and you love two screens on your desktop, you'll probably like the Galaxy Z Fold6 (7\u002F10, WIRED Review). This iteration has a close to “normal” smartphone experience on the exterior 6.3-inch screen. It's still a bit narrow, but it's more usable than its predecessors. Open the phone up and there's a vast 7.6-inch AMOLED screen staring at your face, turning this folding phone into a tiny tablet. You can use your apps in this full-sized view (it's especially great when these apps are tablet-optimized), or you can use split-screen and get two normal-looking app windows next to each other. A persistent taskbar follows you throughout the interface like the dock on MacOS or Windows, letting you hop into another app at a moment's notice. It's great for getting stuff done.\nUnfortunately, the 2024 model got a price bump despite minor changes, and the competition also feels like it has blown past what Samsung has been doing for years—the Pixel 9 Pro Fold has an even more normal exterior screen, and the OnePlus Open has richer multitasking capabilities. Honor's folding phone is also the world's thinnest. Rumors suggest the Galaxy Z Fold7 will be a bigger upgrade with new features and capabilities, so you should wait to see what's new. When you buy a carrier phone, it's “",["a",{"href":"https:\u002F\u002Farstechnica.com\u002Ftech-policy\u002F2024\u002F10\u002Ft-mobile-att-oppose-unlocking-rule-claim-locked-phones-are-good-for-users\u002F","isExternal":false},"locked"],"” to that network. That means if you want to switch carriers, like move from Verizon to T-Mobile, you'll have to ask your carrier to unlock the device, and this can be a huge headache. (Especially if you're traveling and want to use an ",["a",{"href":"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.wired.com\u002Fstory\u002Fhow-to-use-buy-esim-international-travel-trips\u002F","isExternal":false},"international SIM card"],".) Asking a carrier to unlock a phone usually has a few requirements, like making sure your device is paid off, or waiting for a set period of time. Unlocked phones, on the other hand, don't have this problem. You're free to use whatever carrier you want, whenever."],["p","Carriers also mask the true cost of a smartphone. AT&T may entice you with a $36 per month payment for a shiny new Samsung flagship, when in reality, that means you're paying $1,300 on a smartphone over 36 months. Did you really want to spend ",["em","that much"],"? Or will a cheaper phone suffice? Also, you're more likely to get software updates faster as they come directly from Samsung, and there's often far less preinstalled bloatware to deal with."],["p","All to say, buy unlocked! the Galaxy S25 and Qi2"]]],["inline-embed",{"props":{"name":"accordion-panel","attrs":{},"childTypes":[]},"ref":"","type":"callout:accordion-panel"},["p","Qi2 is the new wireless charging standard—it takes a page from Apple's ",["a",{"href":"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.wired.com\u002Fgallery\u002Fbest-magsafe-accessories\u002F","isExternal":false},"MagSafe technology"]," and embeds magnets directly into the smartphone, allowing it to connect to accessories and chargers magnetically, even the same ones available for iPhones. That has the potential to increase the compatibility of accessories across devices, which is a good thing. The magnets ensure precise charging, so you never worry about a misaligned phone that won't charge, it offers better efficiency, and can potentially charge faster. We have more details in our ",["a",{"href":"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.wired.com\u002Fstory\u002Fwhat-is-qi2-wireless-charging\u002F","isExternal":false},"Qi2 explainer here"],"."],["p","Confusingly, Samsung's newest flagship phones are “",["strong","Qi2 Ready"],"” and technically not true Qi2 smartphones. This means that they have the capability to support Qi2 if paired with a ",["a",{"href":"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.wired.com\u002Fstory\u002Fandroid-magsafe-pixel-samsung-peak-design-everyday-case\u002F","isExternal":false},"magnetic case"],", but alone, the S25 series do not have built-in magnets. It's disappointing and creates more confusion, and already I've encountered some cases with varying degrees of magnetic strength, and some cases don't quite work with basic ",["a",{"href":"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.wired.com\u002Fgallery\u002Fbest-wireless-chargers\u002F","isExternal":false},"Qi wireless charging stands"],". That's because Samsung's Galaxy S series flagship phones have long relied on two different processors. Devices sold in the US and select markets are powered by Qualcomm's Snapdragon processors, whereas other regions have Samsung's homegrown Exynos chipsets. Recently, Samsung has opted to use Qualcomm chips globally, though even in the US, some cheaper Samsung phones employ Exynos."],["p","The gap isn't as wide between these processors anymore, but there have been issues in the past. Exynos chips tended to overheat a few years ago, though they sometimes offer slightly better battery life than their Qualcomm counterparts. It even greatly impacted camera quality too as the chip handles the image processing. Again, none of this is ",["em","as"]," big of an issue as it used to be, but it's worth keeping in mind as you shop."]]]]],"outro":["div",["h2","Other Samsung Phones to You can find a list of ",["a",{"href":"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.samsung.com\u002Fus\u002Fsupport\u002Fanswer\u002FANS10001955\u002F","rel":"nofollow","attributes":{"data-offer-url":"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.samsung.com\u002Fus\u002Fsupport\u002Fanswer\u002FANS10001955\u002F"},"isExternal":true},"compatible Samsung phones here"],", and you'll need a ",["a",{"href":"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.wired.com\u002Fgallery\u002Fbest-computer-monitors\u002F","isExternal":false},"monitor"],", ",["a",{"href":"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.wired.com\u002Fgallery\u002Fbest-gaming-mouse\u002F","isExternal":false},"mouse"],", and ",["a",{"href":"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.wired.com\u002Fgallery\u002Fbest-keyboards\u002F","isExternal":false},"keyboard"],", plus a ",["a",{"href":"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.wired.com\u002Fgallery\u002Fbest-usb-c-cables\u002F","isExternal":false},"cable"]," to connect the phone to the monitor. (You can also cast DeX to select screens wirelessly.)"],["ad",{"position":"mid-content"}],["p","When in DeX mode, you can resize Android apps and have them all open in separate windows. It's a proper computing platform, though you probably won't want to use this as a permanent laptop replacement or anything of the sort. It's great if you're visiting another office, or working out of a coffee shop or airplane (if you have a portable display). We have a whole guide ",["a",{"href":"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.wired.com\u002Fstory\u002Fhow-to-use-samsung-dex-mobile-desktop\u002F","isExternal":false},"to setting up and using DeX here"],"."],["h2","How I Test Phones"],["p","I've been reviewing smartphones for a decade, but one of my earliest smart devices was a ",["a",{"href":"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.wired.com\u002F2010\u002F06\u002Fsamsung-android-phone-heads-to-att\u002F","isExternal":false},"Samsung Galaxy Captivate"],", which I got for “free” from my carrier at the time. After working during college, I finally saved enough cash for a ",["a",{"href":"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.wired.com\u002F2012\u002F06\u002Fsamsung-galaxy-s-iii\u002F","isExternal":false},"Galaxy S3"],", my first flagship. I've spent years using Samsung phones in my personal life and began reviewing them for work not too long after."],["p","With each Samsung smartphone, I always put my personal SIM card inside and spend as long as I can (a few weeks) using the phone as my own. I do camera testing and compare the results with similarly priced devices, I benchmark performance and play graphically demanding games to see how they fare, I try out all the new features, and even take calls to make sure that ol' function still works fine."],["hr"],["p",["strong",["a",{"href":"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.wired.com\u002Fv2\u002Foffers\u002Fwir_generic_ctrl?source=Site_0_HCL_WIR_EDIT_HARDCODED_0_COMMERCE_AFFILIATE_ZZ","isExternal":false},["em","Power up with unlimited access to"]," WIRED"],["em","."]]," ",["em","Get best-in-class reporting that's too important to ignore for just ",["del","$2.50"]," $1 per month for 1 year. Not much has changed from its predecessors (seriously, many of the specs are identical), but that doesn't stop them from being excellent and reliable smartphones. The Galaxy S25 is the smallest of the lot with a 6.2-inch screen, and then there's the Galaxy S25+ at 6.7 inches—choosing between them largely depends on whether you want a small, pocketable phone or a big display. There are ",["a",{"href":"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.wired.com\u002Fstory\u002Fwhich-samsung-galaxy-s24-model-to-buy\u002F","isExternal":false},"minuscule differences in some specs"],", such as how the S25+ comes with 256 GB of storage, and the bigger size means a beefier battery, but they're more alike than ever before."],["p","You get every high-end feature you can think of, from UFS 4.0 storage speeds to brilliantly bright AMOLED displays with high ",["a",{"href":"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.wired.com\u002Fstory\u002Fhigh-refresh-rate-explained\u002F","isExternal":false},"120-Hz refresh rates"]," that ratchet down to 1 Hz to be more energy efficient. The batteries typically last a full day of average use with around 30 to 40 percent left, and there's an excellent triple-camera system with 3x optical zoom, an ultrawide in addition to the main camera, and a strong selfie shooter. These phones also put out some of the best video footage out of the box, so they're great for budding TikTokkers. Arguably, the most notable improvement over prior models is performance—the efficient Snapdragon 8 Elite chipset paired with Samsung's improved cooling technology means it can handle demanding games like ",["em","Genshin Impact"]," with fewer stutters and without getting warm too quickly. The late-entry Galaxy S25 Edge sits in the middle of Samsung's flagship lineup and matches several features of the Galaxy S25 Ultra, like a titanium frame, stronger front glass, and 4K 120 fps video recording. All the cameras even have autofocus. But it made several sacrifices to achieve its amazingly slim 5.8-mm frame (for context, the S25 Ultra is 8.2 mm thick). There's no stylus, no telephoto camera, and worst of all, the battery capacity has been slashed."],["p","We've seen this before—thin phones have always compromised on battery life, and that's no different here. I constantly had to baby this phone's 3,900-mAh battery with average to heavy usage, and that's just not acceptable for a $1,100 smartphone today. If you find yourself constantly near a power source and you think you'll enjoy the slim and light design, then go for it. It's still an excellent flagship in many other ways.
